reviewText:
What an interesting game indeed. As similar this game is to Smite and LoL it has its own flair.

Combat 8/10

Combat is fun and exciting as long as you have a good idea of how and when to push and fall back. I think that as a game in whole that is the basic principle. I have lost a lot of games because as a team we don't know when to attack or defend. However why I dock two points is because of collision. Holy crap I have died SO many times because I am getting stuck on everything. I’m sorry but playing Montana and a little rock on the floor stopping me makes no sense.

Replay 7/10

The single player/ Co-Op part of the game is fun but once you beat all the missions you’re just beating your times. I do however like that they are different difficulty’s to play on so it presents a challenge.

Fun 9/10

If this game is anything it is loads of fun. Played a couple nights with my friends and its constant yelling and screaming (in a good way). If you have friends pick this game up with them and you won’t regret it.

reviewText:
I originally hadn't paid much attention to this game. I heard it was from Gear Box which peaked my interest, but it looked like just another MOBA.
During open beta I got bored and decided to give it a try. It's amazing! I use to love Monday Night Combat and I still love Borderlands, so what I got was a perfect combination of the two.

The story mode is very good. It's Borderlands-funny, has a decent story, has multiple difficulty levels, and gives you loot (which you can use to mod your hero).

It's a first person shooter with hero abilities. There's (currently) 3 game modes.

Incursion is like a single laned MOBA. There are jungles (mercenaries) that you can win over to fight on your side and you can build/upgrade towers. You push through two strong sentry tanks to win.

Meltdown is a weird Minion escort" mode where you have to protect your minions all the way up to the sacrifice point. You get points for each minion that is sacrificed and the first team to meet the goal wins.

Capture point is your basic 3 point capture mode where holding a point gives your team points.

There's no pay to win. You can't pay for anything besides when it comes out.

Some people may not like that the game has a high TTK. Sniper is 3-4 headshots on a squishy to kill. It's more about doing the objectives than killing players.

Negatives: Ranked mode isn't implemented yet (It's coming). New players may find the effects too blinding. Lots of colors everywhere! You have to unlock 18 of the 25 heroes (which I like

reviewText:
Pros:

Pretty fun, fast paced, action packed shooter game
Very reminiscent of the Borderlands series
Decent story mode that has good replayability
Large character roster with good progression

Cons:

Not well optimized for most computers
PvP balancing is non existant
ENORMOUS price drop 2 weeks after launch, with zero benefits for the existing playerbase

Overall, I would say this is worth buying since it is a good game. However, out of principle, I can not recommend any game from a company that will cut the price tag by nearly 50% 2 weeks after release, and then give no compensation to the existing playerbase. Had I known this game would be $20 less if I waited a week, I wouldn't have bought it. Bad company decisions.

reviewText:
A great game that admittedly has flaws. First off, I love this game. I think that it's a good blend of the first person shooter style and a MOBA. The heroes are all unique, interesting, and effective. The quality of the environments, the casting, and the gameplay are top notch. However, the game has flaws that need to be addressed.

First of all, the lack of maps is an issue. There are I believe 6 maps in the game currently. 2 for each game mode. That's not very good. Although these maps are all good and allow a variety of playstyles in each, the lack of content is an issue. Whether or not Gearbox desides to make more maps for free or include them in map packs is up to them. But I feel as though they should be making more maps due to the lack of variety.

Secondly, the story is short. The game only has 8 missions. Now, they do have some replayablilty due the fact that some heroes require good rankings on missions to be unlocked and you can get gear to use in and out of multiplayer in these missions. Although these missions last ~30 minutes, there are simply too few of them. You also cannot choose which mission you want to play unless you go solo or with a private group, which is just a puzzling system.

So what your getting is a great experience that lacks in some important areas. If you are even somewhat interested in the game, buy it, you won't be dissapointed. However, if you find yourself on the fence, reading these reviews to make a decision, wait a bit, watch some videos online of gameplay. This game will only satisfy you if you are looking for a new multiplayer game to play, with some occasional distractions in the story mode.

Another thing to keep in mind: this game is a blast with friends

reviewText: I've spent around 80 hours more playing this game (as of 5/4/16) than my Steam Profile shows, between the beta, closed technical test, and PS4 versions of the game. That being said, it's probably one of the most entertaining multiplayer games I've ever played. There's a lot of rock paper scissors style matchups among the characters and different strategies you can utilize as far as loadouts for each character go. The single player missions are a nice way to kill time but honestly not what I bought the game for. I got the Digital Deluxe version with no hesitation because I knew I would get my money's worth in SPITE of already having played the game for 80 hours already, which surprised me to be honest. This is a really fun but also really deep game.\n\nThere are three multiplayer modes (all objective based) with no straight up" PvP. At first I groaned a little bit because it would have been nice but having played the game further I found out I really don't notice it's omission because what the game does provide is pretty damn entertaining. The characters all play really uniquely and you could play one character for weeks (go Team Phoebe!) without getting bored or switch it up and play a traditional FPS oriented character like Oscar Mike. There's a some overlap between characters in terms of their roles on each team (healer

The multiplayer is balanced pretty decently with a few exceptions that are definitely being watched and tuned as during each of the tests I played in Gearbox was very responsive in monitoring the data they received based on matches played

Pros+ Includes a campaign that can be played with others.
+ The character roosters are all interesting and different, 25 in all.
+ Strategic gear loadouts add depth to the system and leveling up to 10 called Helix which unlocks as you battle in game and unlocks the more you play adding more to the characters playstyle.
+ Plenty of lore, items, gears, taunts and skins to unlock.
+ The graphics, introductions, sounds, radio chatter, particles are fun and has influence and similarities  from Borderlands.

Cons- The matchmaking system needs a bit more work.

-  pvp reward is lacking compared to campaign.
- Locked characters that needs to be unlocked even though you bought the game, though not difficult it is still ANNOYING.
- People surrendering too fast sometimes is discouraging.
- Need to be connected at all to do any gameplay at all any interruption and your game will close down.

reviewText:
Welcome to Pub Stomp: The Game

It seems pretty apparent past the first few days that zero effort besides 'pair 5 vs 5 people' was put into the matchmaking system as the system is frequently pairing 5 fully arranged teammates against 5 random people (typically of much lower levels sometimes with level gaps of 30-50 levels between EVERY player on the opposing teams).

Let's also not forget the exploits on the pushing gamemode that allows a Marquis to effortlessly and risk-free kill your first sentinel that they've known about since the betas and apparently decided to just not fix altogether, taking a match that may have been previously something that could've been balanced to a straight ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t fest of abuse of exploits long well known.

Can't really recommend it, while it hs some fun moments if you'replaying alone or with just one other friend its pretty much just a ♥♥♥♥ show full of broken matchmaking.

reviewText:
Product received for free

I've been playing Battleborn since the Beta and had the honor of playing during the early access period for press and content creators.  I've been playing heavily post launch as well.  Overall, I really enjoy Battleborn.  It provides a unique experience that blends several of my favorite genres.  You have FPS, MOBA, Tower Defence elements.  25 characters.  There's three 5v5 PvP modes, 2 maps per mode.  8 Story missions you can play solo or with up to 4 friends (5 player co-op!).  They have tons of free post release content planned (characters, PvP content) as well as some paid story mission DLC.  They've avoided the whole microtransaction deal.  So from a content / value perspective I feel that the price is reasonable.

How does it play?  Well, that depends on the mode.  The story missions play out like a highly arcadified Borderlands, but with a faster pacing and a focus on abilities.  Story missions are typically revolve around escort and defend, with a few playing like a Raid as you'd expect to see in an MMO.  Some are more fun than others, but all of them are enjoyable.  More so if you bring friends along.  The PvP modes are all rather different.  PvP is where this game shines.  Incursion is like a one lane MOBA and full of 5v5 team battles.  Meltdown has heavier tower defense elements, filled with tons of smaller skirmishes.  Capture is your standard deathmatch + hold certain points mode.  There's a lot of variety in both the modes and the characters, I can't help but feel that there's something there for everyone.

They took a lot of risks making this and I feel that it paid off.  There's been some hiccups, but the devs (Gearbox) have been attentive and are working to address the more pressing concerns as quick as they can.

I'd recommend Battleborn.  It's very different and a breath of fresh air.  The pricing model is fair and there's a wealth of content there currently.  There's tons of unlocks, abilities and customizable gear loadouts to keep min/maxers and theorycrafters busy for ages.  It has great depth and strategy.  Plus, it has that awesome humor you'd expect from Gearbox.  I see myself playing for quite a while and am excited to see the competitive scene starting to grow as well.  If you're looking for a fun, unique game to play with friends, I think Battleborn is a good call.

reviewText: I spent upwards of 100 hours in the closed test and open beta, and finally having the full version is like a weight being lifted off of my shoulders. Coming from an extensive Halo upbringing and gravitating to the Smite scene after Halo was CoD-ified, this is a perfect blend of the arena shooters of old and MOBAs. With enough single player content to satisfy the co-op dungeon crawler crowd with more on the way, and non-MOBA game modes for gamers that are burnt out on the League of Legends formula, this game has something for everybody to enjoy. Great characters, unique artstyle, great gameplay, and most importantly, a wholly unique experience compared to other shooters on the market.

reviewText:
I only play PvP Meltdown and I love it.

Its a refreshing change from my usual diet of aim heavy FPS games (Quake, Dirty Bomb etc..) although quite similar to Dirty Bomb in its own way with the combination of team composition, positioning and wave timing being important for success (at least in Meltdown)

I love shooters but find MOBA's too boring, this takes the two styles and makes a whole new fun one of its own.

-- EDIT After playing over another 100 hours --

Still playing Meltdown and still enjoying it as much as the first week. Sure, there are a lot of issues that they need to look at :

1. Matchmaking
2. Frame rate for certain maps (and AMD cards in general)
3. Scoring system encouraging kills rather than objectives (minions etc..)

but the core gameplay is so good that I keep coming back night after night.

There seems to be relatively few games these days where you can really mount an amazing comeback..You're over 100 minions down, 1 guy keeps calling a surrender vote, everyone else is saying keep calm, just get some levels and stick together and slowly but surely everyone starts to focus together, the waves get cleared, you pick off a few kills, the minion scores start to even up and you can feel the other team start to lose hope, they start throwing themselves at you but never quite getting enough kills to turn the tide of the comeback. In the last few minutes of the game the minion scores goes in our favour and its a glorious hard won victory. NEVER SURRENDER.

If you're the kind of person who likes a game with layers and depth that really rewards how much time you put in I can't recommend this enough.

(Again, this is all Meltdown, tbh I think it would have made a great game all by itself)

reviewText:
I've decided to revise my review amongst a torrential stream of negativity surrounding this game, suddenly attacking it at all angles in an attempt to dissuade people from buying Battleborn.
The bottom line is this: If you like MOBA elements as well as FPSers, Battleborn is going to be the perfect blend of coordinated chaos for you and your friends.
Otherwise, maybe steer clear until it's later into its lifespan.

As a game itself, there's virtually nothing wrong with Battleborn. It's a fun, team-coordinated multiplayer (and co-op) experience, with an aesthetically pleasing design and varied roster of characters to choose from. One could complain that it has a lack of map diversity, but that's to be /expected/ from this genre--most of its critics stemming from people that don't understand what a MOBA is anyhow. While there may be a lack in content, Gearbox Software has big plans to expand its size for those who want something more.

This is not an Overwatch killer, nor was it ever supposed to be a competetor. It's something that it lives in harmonious balance with, and Battleborn is and always will be something different; a hybrid-like blend of two very loved types of games currently out on the market. I had a blast with this game, and I will continue to have a blast with it because it's a damn good time.

If you're going to riff on Battleborn, you need to understand that you simply do not like it and that others very much so do. There's nothing wrong with wanting some dumb, action-filled fun in your life, and Battleborn fulfills that want quite well.

Give it a chance.
9/10

reviewText:
First of all, this...
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SAMGrDUSGJU

For anyone in debate over Battleborn VS Overwatch. Now for the review!

I have played both and I personally prefer Battleborn. I love the quirky characters and the way they interact with one another. The characters are easy to fall in love with as far as personality and gameplay and offer much in the way of lore, comedy and story.

Gameplay is much liek a FPS MOBA, minus the intense stress of FPSs like CS:GO, and the boring, grueling nature of DOTA. This game somewhat resembles Smite, with a heaping dash of it's own uniqueness that you can only tuly experience with purchase.

As I said, the characters are easy to fall in love with. Each has their own quirky nature and humor and interactions with other characters and enviromental creatures and characters via PVE or PVP. The lore is fun to achieve, even though it can be tasking and difficult at times to accomplish, but you get to learn about each character, sometimes weapons and you get have a sound dialogue unlocked for each which can either be humorous or, developmental in-depth character insights. The lore also often fills in those gaps in the story that are understandable due to the way the story modes are played.

Story mode and the story in general, while fun, lacks adequate substance. But as I said, the lore provides some much needed cement for gap filling. The story chapters as they stand, are meant ot be played at random and only partially in order, which makes it easy to just ready up with randoms, and not really misso ut on any of the story.

Listen, watch the video if you're in debate about Overwatch VS Battleborn. It will help you to purchase one, or the other or both. I plan on both eventually but for now, Battleborn is my first love and has been since Pax Prime. I've been a loyal fan since and have ventured through their closed technicals and betas. I highly reccomend this game! It's deffinately worth it! But it's my opinion... You really have to make your own judgement!

reviewText:
This is a review of only the story campaign since I don't really play competitive.

Played the beta and I really enjoyed the action this game has to offer.  So many characters to choose from and so many different tactics to take when tackling a boss that its a little overwhelming.  That's not a bad thing though since I really like to sink a lot of hours in a game when I like it.

I feel there is a lot of gamers out there that might be hesitant to buy  a AAA game for $60 so if you are not sure about spending so much then wait for a sale.  To those that are not afraid to spend the dosh on a AAA game this is honestly a very fun experience.  The dialogue is great, the action is chaotic, and the coop is fun but not tedious.  I am only a few hours in but I can already see myself enjoying this game with friends for a while.  How long I enjoy it depends on the games life cycle.  I sank 100 hours in on The Division and the updates literally killed my interest in that game so I ask myself this:  Do I like what I see right now?  Yes.  Will there be more expansions to keep me interested?  Yes.  What kind of end game does this game have? ???  The end game is usually the problem with games of this caliber where they are great but the end game sucks (See Divison).

I am not sure how the end game will play out but for now I will continue to enjoy and explore everything this game has to offer.  I hope that this is the type of game that is prepared for folks like me that conquer games in a week or so because I really enjoy what I have seen so far.

Graphics- 8.5
Borderlands style of Art but with a little more animation and crispness

Controls- 9.5
Easy to pick up and play, but hard to master all characters.  I mean there is so many abilities!

Playability- 10
Graphics are fully adjustable and the action plays pretty consistent at 50fps-60fps, even at the most chaotic times.  I play on laptop and for some reason it doesn't even heat up my rig that much, maybe 10 degrees Celsius hotter than idle.  (GTX 960m 2 gb Vram I 5700HQ)

Replay Value- To be determined
I said earlier in the review its all about the end game, but the road to get there must be fun to play over and over again because some friends will be behind me in the story.

reviewText:
So, there are those rare occurances that the David can dropkick the Goliath, kick him in the balls and then ♥♥♥♥ on his face.

If you replace the David with Battleborn, and Goliath with Overwatch, I think you've got a pretty solid statement.

Played the hell out of the beta and am not disappointed one bit, this game is one of those rare occasions where it manages to bring games back to the way they were, when shelling out 60 bucks would mean something instead of getting you a DLC simulator. Looking at you, CoD... Just kidding, I still love you. ANYWAYS.

What I'm trying to say is, this game is worth every penny, because the amount of content and replayability to this game is ASTONISHING. I haven't played a game this complete since I was a kid, flicking on my N64 and wrecking house. This is a game pushing paid DLC into the minor, making paid DLC a complementory aspect of the game. But, they're also expanding onto the game with free DLC! It's a mixture of the past and the present, and the best parts of the gaming community as a whole, and people still continue to talk ♥♥♥♥ on this beautiful work of art!

Play this game. These developers deserve a round of applause for the game they've created. Maybe if we all take in techniques like this, and support these kinds of games, we can get full complete games back. The only way they'll know that we want things back to the way they were, before DLC simulators... Is to support the games that are fully complete.

I hope I'm not the only one that misses the time when you didn't have to buy the DLC out of a game in order to get the full 60 dollar experience. Maybe I am, we'll find out if Battleborn is still standing months after its release.

reviewText: Great game. I first went in warily in the closed technical test and honestly my first impressions were not great. I returned to the game in its open beta and man did it just hit all the right buttons. I just played and played and played. At its core battleborn is closest to either Monday Night Combat or Smite. It is not as Moba as smite nor as shooter as MNC but some nice balance in the middle. The characters are diverse and the game modes are fun. Though I havent had a chance to play the capture point mode at this time. The story mode has some legs with its variable banter between characters and the NPCs of the missions changing depending on who is involved. Their are also challenges and different difficulty settings that make them replayable. I see at least 15-20 hours in the campaign before new stories get added with DLC. On the subject of DLC and what WILL be DLC from what I gathered it is the followoing. We will be getting 5 more characters added to the game for free some time after launch. The season pass adds instant access to those characters while those without will have to unlock them their normal way (either from reaching certain rank checkpoints, playing against certain characters in PvP/PvE, or just winning so many games, usually their is 2 ways to unlock each character). The upcoming paid DLC seems to be more story missions.\n\nSome negatives since their are a couple. I think optimizations needs to be worked on a bit. Their is some delay that I think I fixed by messing around with the settings. The game is quite challenging in multiplayer and it is easy to feel like you arent doing much untill you come to understand exactly what is going on.

reviewText:
To me, battleborn is definitely underrated when compared to big names such as Overwatch, CS: GO etc etc.

But in all of seriousness, do not compare Battleborn to Overwatch, they maybe both FPS-Moba genre games, but they have so much more differences in it.

Just take some good example is the PVE in battleborn and the helix upgrade for each level. OW doesn't have helix upgrade each level, but they can swap to different characters on the fly when they die to counter a specific match up, and they do not have PVE. I can go on and rant a huge list but nah, I'll just leave the main point here :)

While Battleborn can be played solo/single player (Including a complimentary Prologue, Chapter 1-8), I strongly suggest to go co-op for PVE too. It's fun to play PVE with other players!

There is alot more to be done too, such as completing the lore challenges for each unique character is quite challenging too! Well I guess if it's too easy then there's no point in it right? xD

On the other side, the PVP features 3 modes with 2 maps each:

Capture mode (OUTBACK, TEMPLE): This is just like King of the hill, there are 3 points and objectives to be captured, then defend it from the enemy who will try to claim it back. The team reaches 1000 point wins! It's quite strategic and fast paced too due to switching from offense to defense, and from defense to offense.

Incursion mode (ECHELON, OVERGROWTH <-- most voted map): Have you ever played DotA2 or League of Legends or even Heroes of the Storm? If you played any one of them, Incursion's gameplay is exactly the same in the form of FPS. 5v5, guide your minions to enemy territoy and destroy enemy's sentries to win! To me, Incursion is the most fun game because I play alot of League of Legends.

Meltdown mode (PARADISE, COLDSNAP): In this mode you need to sacrifice your minions to win ): I'm serious! Guide your minions to the minions grinder, to get points. The bigger the minion, the more points you gain. But it ain't gonna be that easy, enemies will try to destroy your minions before it reachers the grinder, so you need to do the same too! First to reach 500 wins. Legitimate a WINnion mode xD

While Gearbox can still give a little bit tweak here and there especially with match-making, other than that this game is pretty fun and worth it. I'd say it improved alot more from the closed and open beta phase.

I'll rate it 7.5/10

Peace out guys and have a #badass day!

reviewText:
Didn't care about the game for a while. Tried the beta and got hooked. I wasted a whole weekend on just the beta.

This game is the perfect blend of Shooters and Mobas. The characters feel fun and creative, the maps are colorful and the whole style just makes me think of Saturday Morning Cartoons. Though there may be some more balancing needed (which will always be needed for these kinds of games) it's not as bad as other games that's been out for years.

The game also brings PvE which has a feel to dungeons in MMOs. You select the chapter, fight mobs, fight boss, fight mobs, fight boss, then fight final boss. It's a good way to get gear to take back to PvP.

The game isn't without issues, I feel that sometimes the screen can feel a little cluttered and it does take a little bit to get use to it, but after that 5th match you no longer care, it's just chaotic fun. Hell I've had so much fun playing Benedict that I didn't even care that my team was losing.

Battleborn is probably the most unique game to come out this year so far and with it's fun cartoony style and it's Borderland's humor, it's a good pick.


Edit: Please nerf that Zelda Warrior

reviewText: This game is fantastic. I know time spent isn't very long but I played the beta loads.\nTo start off, It's interesting abilites and different characters gives a nice spice up to games to the point where I haven't seen one character picked more frequnetly. They are all unique and easily distigiushable among each other creating a scenario where all characters fill a well made niche of play style. I suppose you could call them Minion camps that you can kill to gain an advantage but by no means is it a MOBA in the traditional sense. That said. It's also [/b] nothing like Overwatch  because it actually has depth and fun gameplay. Overwatch  has no upgrading, leveling, all the characters play about the same, no customization, no building of characters and no progression whereas Battleborn has every single element I just listed along with an engaging party campaign. I don't care how much money Blizzard has injected Overwatch with, it doesn't mean they can dominate the market with a game that, lets face it, barely innovates on a tired formula. If you had to pick one, I would go with Battleborn on an account of it having actual depth and replayability other than Overwatch's I hope it's a different guy playing Reaper this time!". I'm not going to suck Gearbox's ♥♥♥♥ because they did such a great job at Borderlands 1 and 2 and give them a free pass on Battleborn. There were expectations to be met, a certain level of polish and depth to this game that seemed like it was promised but never truly delivered.

If you want to get a TL;DR, here's my YouTube version containing a very condensed version of why I gave it the rating I did.

Video Link

Let's start off with the marketing. Nonexistent from what I've seen. While I'm being bombarded by Overwatch ads on YouTube, on billboards, on the buses and subways of New York, Gearbox has decided that their Borderlands fanbase alone would be enough to keep players chugging along with the so-called story" missions to grind up to get items that are supposed to help you in PvP. reviewText:
Great combat (Think Borderlands with 25 playable characters and 3 actives each), charming yet familiar art-style, great soundtrack and phenomenal voice work, Battleborn takes a lot of what I hated in Borderlands 2 and does the right thing; throws it in the trash.

This feels like going back to Borderlands 1, I've played around 6 hours at the time of this review and I have laughed a lot. Lots of running gags, as well as quick witty one-liners that will either hit you straight away, or have you laughing 20 seconds after you heard 'em. The writing would be one of my favourite things about this game, if the gameplay and voice work/characterisation wasn't so damn good too.

Seriously, the amount of effort put into the characters is crazy. They have SO many lines for so many situations, often calling other Battleborn by name, either friend or foe. I don't think I've run into one character who isn't likable, but I have run in a good number who are downright lovable.

But I think my absolute favourite thing has to be the gameplay overall. I love progression systems, and although I know they're not everyone's cup of tea, I love it when you can progress the same character(s) over different game modes, Rainbow Six Vegas coming to mind for this. The multiplayer is very fun, and I didn't even buy the game for the multiplayer, in fact I wasn't going to bother with it at all, but I hopped in a game after (failing) the first proper story mission and I've been hooked all damn day, it doesn't seem to get boring like other shooters, or even other mobas. The Co-Op is difficult. Like, sometimes it can be very difficult, I guess it just depends who you are playing with but the game does a great job at keeping you on your toes.

I just hope more people will get to play this game and have as much fun as I'm having, especially when living in the shadow of the giant Overwatch, which had its beta while this game launched.

Do note this game is not without flaws, performance is a bit weak as usual for Gearbox PC ports, the servers have been iffy all day, especially matchmaking, and I hear AMD GPUs are having massive problems with the game at the moment, hopefully drivers and/or Gearbox fix this.

As other reviews have mentioned, Matchmaking is very poor. This is something GB have acknowledged and are well on the way to fixing, but seriously, it's bad. That's the only thing I dislike about this game.

As I said, the game isn't flawless, but it's pretty damn close.

reviewText:
If ya liked monday night combat youll love this game, its an FPS through and through with elements of tower defense and moba lane pushing (in some modes).

It has gearboxs trademark borderlands humor which gives life to the cast of unique characters.

The story modes are rewarding to play with loot for all.

The content policies are also nice, every thing that looks like a microtransaction in the game comes with the 60 bucks you pay. bank slots, extra loadouts, skins, and loot packs all can be earned or bought with in game currency you also earn by just playing the game. Free dlc with be coming out for at least the next year which includes characters, maps, and modes. Aswell as some cheap story mode dlc for 5 bucks a pop.

Aside from a few expect bugs at launch and no deserter penalty in a game like this, i think this is a solid game that will be  beloved by many but maybe not known by a majority, to soon to say. So if you spend your money on it im sure there will always be a community to play with.

reviewText:
You can't really fault the pseudo anime/action comic/superhero presentation of Battleborn. It exudes swagger and charm with a pumping soundtrack that hits all the right notes along with strong voice acting and a varied cast of characters.

So far I've done a few of the story missions, it does indeed seem possible to fail and it's not a snooze fest at all, there is elements of positional strategy at play though it is not a tightly tuned endeavour that novices will have trouble picking up quickly which is refreshing.

The various characters are all very different in play style and function and the helix and loadout systems allow you to fine tune the way you play.

So far it's an enjoyable co-op gun-show that facilitates team play without any high end co-ordination required making it, so far, very light on toxic attitude.

I've not touched the pvp yet but I would be inclined to think that it's going to be a blast.

reviewText: Honestly, i can't say anything that'll do justice to this game since i can't find words to describe it properly. I do recommend checking some gameplay videos to see what this game's about.\nWhat i can safely say is: I thoroughly enjoyed Borderlands 1 and 2. I've never been into DotA-likes because they felt boring to me. I love this game. Played almost 20 hours in the beta and want to keep playing it.\nPD: At the time of writing this review, there's some optimization issues. Playing at 1080p borderless windowed and everything else on low/off i get 60+ fps with very few dips below that on a R9 270x. I'll update the review if Gearbox/AMD fixes it.

reviewText:
Extremely fun multiplayer. Sadly compared to Overwatch because of some vague similarities. Couldn't be farther from the truth. Co op Campaign, multiple game types and a fairly robust roster of characters to choose from. The multiplayer has APECTS of MOBA gameplay in it like minions and towers, it also has features like merc recruitment (Like HoTS and the like). The color vomit can get a BIT frustrating at times but with enough practice you more or less get a feel for whats going on each match.

I have heard multiplayer DLC will be free with the season pass emcompassing the new co op campaign missions and a few other things. Battleborn released after release will be abe to be unlocked once they come out for free via challenges.

All in all a very overlooked gem with the entry price if you're interested in a unique experience.

reviewText: Battleborn is my favorite game of 2016 so far.  I don't generally play FPS games, but the art style, MOBA components, and interest from my friend group sold me on this game.  This game has a similar blend of charm and humor that made the Borderlands titles so strong.  It has some quirks, but the Gearbox team has been vigilant on listening to community feedback and addressing concerns thus far.  For example, major geometry and design changes have been made to the MOBA-style Incursion map Overgrowth" that fixed cheesy sniper strats.  GB has been quick on balance changes as well

reviewText:
I am so far about 23 hours into this game and I do enjoy it a lot. It reminds me a lot of Super Monday Night Combat. The humor is pretty damn good and the story is well written as well as the playable characters having their own story. I know additional content will be added to this game so I have already taken that into consideration on this review.

The things I love about this game:
-Co-op, Team based pvp and private solo play
-Fleshed out universe and story driven characters
-Easy to play but hard to master
-humor

The things I am ok with:
-The combat can be pretty hectic at times, tons of color and explosions.
-The unlock system.

The things I wish were better:
-More options, such as scaling down the weapons modeals, they take up a lot of screen space.
-Small technical issues, such as mouse lag.
-More unique skins for our heroes.
-Map voting for Story co-op.

I know I could probably go on and on and add pro's and con's but I want to play more. All in all I think it is a solid investment at its asking price. I try to be smart with my money. But this game itch's a particular itch I didnt know I had. I definately recomend it to my friends.

PS. And no its not even close to Overwatch, completely different in my honest opinion.

reviewText:
After almost 25-30 hours of gameplay, I can say that this game is really, really good. What is this game, though? Well, it takes the MOBA genre and turns it on it's head; for once, finally, we get a MOBA where we have full control of our characters and it's no longer mouse-clicking spam garbage.

It's an actual MOBA that plays a bit like a first person shooter. Funnily enough, it streamlines a few things, while delivering some unique new aspects to this style of game that I haven't really seen anywhere else.

Instead of towers being pre-placed, you can build turrets, traps, and things to help your team and hinder the enemy team. Also, instead of random creeps, there are several mercenary camps (At least in Incursion) where you can hire more, bigger, powerful creeps to assault the enemy.

Characters have true skilltrees in the form of a Helix. Each Helix has 2 sides, and every time you level, you can select one or the other to truly customize how your character will play, and how their kit works. Plus, as you gain character levels (outside of each match) you get mutations for your Helix, which give you a third choice for several of the existing helix choices.

Items in a MOBA are simplified now - you make a loadout with three pieces of gear, and when you select your character, you pick a loadout. Those 3 pieces go with you and you craft them with shards as the battle progresses. Simple. ♥♥♥♥ League's system, anyway.

It's a solid game with a lot of stuff going for it, so if you're into playing a game that involves a bit of strategy and teamwork, this should be a definite buy for people, especially if you enjoy playing it with friends.

NOTE: This game is NOT comparable to Overwatch. OW is Blizzard's attempt at making a TF2 clone that is incredibly light on content. They give you 20-ish heroes that don't have a ton of depth. You can't customize the playstyle of your chosen hero, and your rank-up system is purely cosmetic. Plus, you only have two game modes (which are copied directly from TF2, I might add) and there is NO PvE element. So, if you like co-op more than PvP, good luck with that. (I mean, even TF2 has PvE now.. and has had it forever now. Come on, Blizzard.)

Get this game. You won't regret it.

reviewText:
TL;DR: It's not TERRIBLE, but it's not AMAZING. Most games can do it's individual components better.

It's a great gap filler so far since beta, the prologue cutscenes are pretty ♥♥♥♥ing trippy. Pick it up if you just can't wait for other titles, otherwise this title remains to be seen on what it's going to provide. I'm not expecting anything much out of it, as I know Overwatch is something I'll play more.

Update: After playing- I can say my suspicions were not quite as expected. Whilst the game has a lot of flaws (and balance issues!) it appears to be relatively firm and stable- and the only major issue people seem to be running into is frames-per-second/preformance issues.

As it so stands, it turns out so far I have played this more than Overwatch. Maybe that's just me getting sidetracked again, though.

Unfortunately, I can see slight echos of Evolve- especially with ThisAint being a moderator on this game's forum. That was gasoline on the steam community fire for that game. reviewText:
well, the game has been out for 23 days and is already on sale for 40 percent off. Here is just a quick Pros and Cons
Pros:
-25 heroes
-interesting multiplayer

Cons:
-Short story
-the short story has absolutely no plot
-characters are all way too silly
-Boss battle is lame and recycles old bosses
-point a to point B linear crap
-heroes are so diverse that you will not be able t play/ don't enjoy 60% of them(At least with me)
-3 modes, 2 maps
-1 mode is for MLG Noscoperz (Capture)
-Balance is not amazing
-gear system is stupid
-has a supply drop system just asking for microtransactions
-Gear has very little impact on the match
-Takes forever to geth some characters (Ghalt and Kleese)
-Game feels like it should be free to play
-should be in Alpha

May sound like I was a hater, but exact opposite up until launch. There is not enough content in the game, and a good chunk of the present content is not good. If they would have spent resources they put into the story and comic series into multiplayer maps and making heroes slightly more similar (I know I am talking about skill gap compression, but too many are just unplayable), this would be a great game. I would advise that you pass, even with this promotion. My advice is that you buy the Witcher 3 for 25 bucks instead.

Battleborn is best classified as an FPS MOBA. This means it would function in a very different way to Overwatch, a Class-Based FPS. Whoever decided to come up with the buzzword Hero Shooter" and classify them both together should probably be shot.

Balancing issues exist. This is simply a fact about any competitive game. As with just about any competitive game

reviewText: Played the beta during it's release and only managed to play for around 10 hours, finishing one story mission and a few mulitplayer games. I thought it was pretty dank but wasn't too sure if it justified spending £40. Two days after release and the dankness has shifted into maximum overdrive. It hit me like a gust of fresh air from the engine of an A380 about to take off. Offering a single-player/ co-op storymode campaign and multi-player with a levelling and loot system, there's tons of replayabilty. It's like that first time you and your mates got so high but everytime you play this you get that same, great high, making you want to play it again and again. Characters are interesting, many of which unique and very fun to play. Have noticed some take lots of inspiration from Dota or TF2 characters such as Benedict-Soldier from TF2 and Ghalt-Pudge from Dota with great similarities to Roadhog from Overwatch. Currency system allows you to purchase loot packs to unlock cool gear to better you in-game such as extra reload speed, shield capacity, etc with a rarity system. The characters themselves have a lot of pop-culture references to which I find pretty cool such as Rath's mic drop" taunt reminiscent of Obama at his final correspondent's dinner and other occurences such as when Neil deGrasse Tyson demolished B.o.B's flat earth theory on Comedy Central.\n\nWould definitely recommend to anyone

reviewText: Battleborn is the newest game from Gearbox games with the same tongue in cheek humor as the Borderlands series.  With 24 heroes and more to come, Battleborn is an arena shooter with the skill building mechanics similar to MOBAs. While not inherently a MOBA itself, Battleborn does take a lot of elemets from many genres and smashes them together. In essence there is a hero for any play type and a whole lot to play in the game. The Story mode is good clean fun that you can play co-op with friends or random strangers that really brings out the games humor. If you keep your mind open to the game your sure to have a lot of fun with it.

reviewText:
It's ok...I guess. Because of me playing the beta and loving it, this game grabbed my attention. And it worked. And it's not THAT great, but still fun to play.

The campaign is short, and not that interesting (that opening cutscene tho). But the multiplayer is fun though and you'll be wasting your time on that. It has the Borderlands type of humor that we expect to see, and it does work. Gameplay is fun. It does not reach the same fun factor as the Borderlands games but it's still good.  AI is completely brain dead in the campaign though. Some enemies don't even move until they're like half a life left, and adding in more enemies does not make the game difficult, it just makes it annoying.

This isn't as heavily praised as I gave to the Borderlands series, but it does not make it a bad game. Just an average one. It's still worth my recommendation though, just wait until it goes on sale or when there is a price drop for this title.

reviewText:
Ok after seeing some of the stupid reviews this game is getting, i had to put in my two cents. For starters ANY review that is comparing this to Overwatch is completely pointless. Do your research and see that they are both two different games that people are trying to lump in the same category. Anyway....

A key point about battleborn:

-If you don't like Mobas such as league of legends, smite, heroes of the storm, or Dota 2, then you're going to want to reconsider buying this game. Everything about this game is in the moba styling even in Story Missions (which i've played mobas for almost 5-6 years now so i have no problems with this) but it's incredibly important to know what you're getting yourself into. Competitive players that curse you out when they are also failing, balancing issues at times, lack of teamwork, lack of direction towards objectives, and meta picking champs are all going to be part of the multiplayer in this game. As much as i hate what i just mentioned, it's sadly part of the community. So if you dont like minion killing along lanes, cant deal with toxic players, or don't like repetitive matches on the same maps, then stray away from battleborn. Last thing we need is the reviews plummeting because some kid didn't do his research, thought about gearbox and borderlands, then writes a review saying it sucks.

Battleborn~
Pros:
-Wonderful and creative character roster. Very unique with lots of different play styles. Want to be a gentleman robot sniper who calls people hobos? Marquis is right there for you! Want to cut people down with swords and have a skill calling Totally not a vampire"? Rath is for you. Want some stealth with holo decoys? Deande is perfect for you!

reviewText:
Battleborn has really impressed me with it's fun and dynamic game style, ever since i saw it first on youtube i knew one thing for sure that this game is going to be great! 7/10 from me !

Pro's
- Fun Gameplay
- Good Story
- Well balanced characters
- Fluid Combat Mechanics
- Good Upgrade System
- Great Graphics
- Spectacular use of Animated Cutscenes with amazing music
- Hardcore AI
- Challenging Bosses

Con's
- Only some characters like Oscar mike can use iron sights, most characters just have a secondary melee ability that i feel is very lacking.
- Some characters as they appear in cutscenes fly, but in gameplay they just hover. They should be allowed to fly in game.
- There is no ability to crouch, that makes the game lack sniping abilities. The sniping factor in this game is purely situational and mostly on the move.
- While there is no lag in multiplayer games, quick commands and some more features that can make players interact with each other inorder to work as a team could be better.

*Gear Box, if you can involve some asthetics and features from games like Transformers Fall of cybertron (Multiplayer) then it would be great.*

reviewText: Enjoyable enough, though I do admit that I regret paying the full $60 price tag. I would have been more content with a $40-$45 price tag. Though perhaps this is just my cheap nature that is the result of my inability to stay with one game for an extended period of time. I believe I'll get 30 hours out of this game, but I doubt any more than that.\n\nThe game play is fun and addictive. I've never played any MOBA before, but I have still found myself enjoying this game. The story mode is alright and the multiplayer is pretty intense. I also absolutely adore the visuals. My 290x can run this game at beautiful settings, however my laptop that sports a 970M, seems to struggle to max out settings. Nvidias recommended resolution is at 900p. Looks fine I guess, but still a bit of a let down. Pretty colors, pretty world, awesome gameplay.

reviewText:
I find this game very fun to play. It's fast paced, the characters are actually interesting and the game looks nice.

There are a few balancing issues in the game, but it was just released; that's to be expected (not nearly as bad as some of the balancing problems in Overwatch right now; looking at you, Zenyatta. You're so weak you're almost unplayable...). Mostly just 1 character in all honesty, you see her every game. Galilea for those who haven't played yet.

Not enough supports in my opinion right now, but the ones we do have are actually nice. Though Miko is the best one in general, sadly. Would be nice to get more, which we probably will.

Character personalities are very well done, I personally find myself playing Shayne and Aurox constantly. Great fun to be had there.

Story missions can be very long and grindy, but that's after you've beaten them and simply wish to get silver or gold. First time going through? Very fun, long, fleshed out, and it tends to be funny. You can see allot of Borderlands style in the game.

While there are downsides in the game, they are very forgivable when you look at the big picture. The game is worth it in my opinion, I don't regret buying it at full price. If you're looking for a fun multiplayer game to play, this one's a great one to look into.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
I was so ready to hate this game, since I really wanted to see Gearbox do a return to form with dark humor and a new Borderlands game that got away from the Handsome Jack crap and focused again on carnage and black humor.  But Battleborn is where Gearbox's heart lies now, and honestly...

... I'm really into it.  I loved the beta.  And I love the release even more.  In Battleborn they seem to have successfully uncoupled the zany humor from the bad, bad, bad and maudlin 'drama' of Borderlands 2 and the Pre-Sequel (though BL2 was the worst offender by far).  Battleborn does what Gearbox does best and nothing else - RPG shooter action with great world design and writing that's hilarious and over-the-top and sometimes you feel like an immature ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ laughing at the humor, but you laugh anyways.

The old-school anime cinematics and hip hop theme were a huge surprise and transported me back into my youth.  Anime of the early 90's and late 80's, upbeat hip hop... it sets the tone for the game, which is honestly like playing a Gorillaz music video, which I dig.

In so many ways, this is not 'just another something' even though I was ready to barf when I heard about MOBA elements.  Yet, there is nothing MOBA about this, in terms of the community it fosters and the attitudes it encourages.  I played several versus matches and had a great time.  Who knew?

Sure, the game is wackadoo.  But it knows what it is, and like any well-composed work of art, it sticks close to its themes and always exercises continuity, in especially subtle ways.  It never loses its way.

On top of that, it plays like a dream and if you have friends, forget about it - you'll have a blast.

And on top of THAT, the system in place for progression and unlocking characters, gear, etc. is incredibly fair, intuitive, and requires ZERO real-world cash purchasing.  This is not a convoluded microtransaction skinner box, this is a game that rewards you for loving it, rather than exploits you for loving it, as so many cynical online games do these days.

I cannot recommend Battleborn enough.

However, I feel like this game has come out at a VERY inopportune time, a time when Blizzard (known for some rather... aggressive business tactics) is releasing a game that is somewhere near the same genre. This will likely cause the game to collapse before it even has a chance of flourishing.\n\nAlthough I don't think the games are nearly as comprable as Blizzard would have people believe, I feel that Battleborn is actually the better overall game when compared to Overwatch. I feel this way for a number of reasons, foremost of which is the fact that GB as a developer is more trustworthy to me. This might at first glance appear blasphemous: how could any developer be more trustworthy than Blizzard, the pinoneer in gaming?" reviewText: This is a great FPS/MOBA that got overshadowed by the only tangentally similar Overwatch. Completely different game and a lot of fun in it's own right. Has the goofy writing of the Borderland's series, well done hand-drawn special effects, and a number of interesting characters.\n\nThe main drawback is the low population of the game at the moment, which is a real pity. As a multiplayer based game this can be a drawback to people, however as someone who lives in Japan I have had very little problem finding matches. The matchmaker suffers further from the low population, having a limited pool of players to draw from and thereby games of uneven skill level being present. There are some complaints on timegated content, however everything in the base game is unlocked through acheivements or play time similar to Super Smash Brothers.

reviewText:
At this point in time, I have bought this game twice (for the Xbox One and PC), and honestly I would buy it a third time.


The game can start slow- each PVE mission can take upwards of 45 minutes solo, maybe 30 if you have a speedy matchmaking team. Even the shortest of PVP games can take near 20 min. I Think this turns away a lot of players used to speedy rounds in other games- Killing another player in PVP requires downing their shield (A bit like Halo, if you will) and their health; as opposed to just their health. PVE enemies work the same way.

Other reviews I've read complain about long matchmaking queues, I honestly don't find them overly abhorrent. At the most, I've waited 3 minutes. This also fluctuates on the time of day you're playing the game and your wifi connectivity.

Another thing I've seen complained about is the lag- while the style of the game appears pretty simple, There are a lot of effects and other visual stuff"- It takes a pretty beefy computer to run. Mine's a fairly tankish machine and I still had to turn the graphics down. (My tip there is to keep the Textures at a high setting and turn the View distance down; it still looks pretty good.) Wifi also takes a role here.


-CHARACTERS-

You start with 5 of 25 base characters
date: discluding the extra 5 that are coming out as DLC.\nThe rest of the characters are unlockable through either raking up
recommended: or specific challenges (Like killing 800 of X enemy

reviewText: I admit I was unsure on this game at first due to the fact that I haven't really been much of a MOBA game player. I love Borderlands (All games but especially 2) so when I had a chance to try the betas I jumped on it. I found myself bewildered at first because there are so many options and characters but you quickly get used to it. The game has that wonderful Humor (and several voice actors from Borderlands you will recognize as characters in Battleborn), colorfull look, and first person combat feel of Borderlands, but it's overall a very different game. It's not about weapons as much as it is leveling your characters, recieving loot items at the end of missions that increase your stats or abilities, and finding characters that work for your play style. There are a ton of things to discover and learn about each character, it will definately keep you busy doing so. I admit I haven't played as much of the competitive multiplayer as I did the campaign since release and during both Betas, but looking forward to that. The game is going to be a life snatcher for awhile, as you will want to try each character and find your niche. On a Nvidia GTX970 with everything maxed and running at 1440p, my Framerates hover at 60fps 90 perfent of the time only dipping when the action is at heaviest points, and even then not much. Very polished and well worth a try if you enjoyed Borderlands and like MOBA games like SMITE.

reviewText:
Product received for free

A friend bought this for me as a gift to play with him. I never played Borderlands so I am more or less new to GearBox's brand and style.

First I will get in the bad: Game doesnt run as well as I would like it, though a driver update has improved the quality significantly. The sfx can sometimes be a wee bit clippy but it is mostly negligeble.

Now onto the good, The game very much feels like Unreal Tournament and [INSERT YOUR FAVORITE MOBA HERE] had a twisted bizzaro baby. This baby was subsequently thrown into a cellshaded vat made out of jelly beans and Monster Energy drinks. I am still walking through the story mode and havent done any competative but I can definitely see myself spending more time here, especially if some more optimazation is done. I love the writing and humor as well cuz it has me chuckling a few times per mission. The characters are each very unique and feel like they add to the action in their own way.

Now would I buy this game? Honestly, I am very much a bargain hunter and indy guy, where I will wait even years to try out games I find interesting, so 59.99 is too rich for my blood anbd if it wasnt for my friend buying it, I would probably be grinding my Path of Exile build instead. However, if a price like that is not a hinderance for you, and you like fast action MOBA style fps and have a more up to date rig to really get the full shine out of the game, Go for it.

reviewText:
This game is absolutely fantastic. I spent this week testing all the upcoming games, Overwatch, Paladins, and Paragon. Every single one of them was an OK game, but each was missing something. Battleborn hit the mark perfectly. It's a fast paced FPS-MOBA with individual character progression, skins, achievements and titles, and an interesting PvE gameplay.

The combat and playstyle is very smooth and organic, and each character (currently 25 available) has a unique play style that makes each play-through refreshing and interesting, combined with a levelling system that lets you customize each ability every time you play.

The majority of downvotes are either complaints about 'repetitive' story (this is primarily a MOBA, and the missions are still fun even after multiple play throughs) and the fact that people somehow missed the fact that this is a MOBA and not Borderlands 3.

As for the multiplayer, it consists of three gamemodes a capture point, Meltdown (minion push), and a standard MOBA type, but with a twist. I will not cover the capture point gamemode here as that is as you can imagine. Meltdown consists of two teams attempting to push waves of minions into the opposing team's portals in order to sacrifice them to appease a god. Their standard MOBA match consists of two giant siege-spider-tank things that must be destroyed in order to win, throughout the course of the match you can hire stronger minions by defeating them around the map, and purchase various towers such as a speed-boost and a health regen.

The overall playstyle is very unique and cannot easily be compared to any game that is currently out. On the whole it is leagues above the other games I mentioned, although that is of course somewhat subjective.

TL;DR

Buy it, Try it, Refund it if you don't like it.

reviewText:
Short Version:
An FPS/MOBA hybrid that manages to blend the two decently, although not without its faults.
All in all, I'd give it an 7-8/10
Strengths:
-Very diverse cast of characters both asthetically and from a gameplay standpoint
-Has a single-player/co-op mode
-Slower, more methodical approach to combat despite the frantic pace of matches
-Despite the above, skirmishes are not just a game of numbers.
-Multiple game types

Weaknesses:
-Polarizing Gearbox humor (but at least a certain writer isn't present anymore)
-All the visual effects can be very overwhelming and encumbering, especially for melee characters
-Co-Op is not worth the price alone
-Rather grindy

Take Monday Night Combat, make it an FPS. And what do you have? Battleborn!

Battleborn is an FPS/MOBA hybrid (read: not a class-based shooter!) that pits two teams of five players against each-other in a variety of game modes. Some of which are what you'd expect from a MOBA, and others of which hold deeper roots in more traditional FPS objective-based gameplay (i.e., KoTH). There's currently three modes now, but I have a feeling there may be more if the playerbase proves to hold steady. Thanks to being an FPS, everything is a skillshot"

reviewText:
Battleborn is a Multiplayer, Co-op FPS game that is REALLY fun. Gearbox dida good job yet again. The game is filled with different characters, each with a different backstory, and skill set, and its just a overall fun game.

- Before I start talking about the game itself, I want to clear some things up. I am NOT comparing Battleborn to Overwatch, simply because they are nothing alike. Besides the graphics, and the fact that they're both FPS's, they are two TOTALLY different games. So, keep that in mind as you are reading this review, that I will NOT be comparing the two games. I'm also not saying that Overwatch is bad, either, so dont start thinking that.

In Battleborn, you are, well, the Battleborn, and your job is to stop Rendain and the Jennerits from rebuilding the Heliophage, and destroying the last star, Solus. In some ways, this game is very similar to the Borderlands games, which I absolutly LOVED. The campaign can be difficult at times, and may require you to go and do the campaign online. Now, the campaign isn't that long: only 8 missions. However, each mission can take up to about 30 mins, so your time and money isn't being wasted. Each mission has the chance to unlock a new character. Characters can be obtained 1 of 3 ways: by completing a challenge, by reaching a certain rank, or beating a mission that unlocks said character.

Now, let's move on to the PvP aspect of the game. There are 3 different modes of PvP: Capture, witch is your standard capture area and hold it for a certain amount of time, Incursion, which is just destroy the enemies base, and Meltdown, but it's basically, you have to sacrifice your minions to a god, which is actually unique.

Overall, I really enjoyed this game. i recommend it to everyone. It truely won't disapoint you. May our battle, never end.

reviewText:
For a quick version of this review:
Battleborn is a very deep and strategic game including PvP with in-match character growth via their helix, long times to kill, mechanics that punish death, and a focus on PvE and tower defense amide the PvP.

The PvE includes 8 missions that contain a mix of escort, protect the objective, and 'raid' (as in enemies to mini-boss to enemies to boss) mechanics.

In public match making for PvE people vote on a random selection of four missions.

There is progression system that includes unlocking characters and extra options on their helix tree.

The five characters being added in the future and all future PvP related material can be accessed for free (but if you own the season pass you just skip the step of unlocking the characters).

The major issues with this game are that it has optimization issues and when you first start out and the system doesn't have any data on you, you may end up in some one-sided matches.

Personally I really like the game and feel like I got my full 60 dollars worth.

Now for some extra details for those still reading:
I definitely recommend this game, but at the same time I do not recommend it to everyone. In the PvP, this is not a typical team based FPS, and whatever you have learned in other FPS likely will not carry over into this game. It definitely has a learning curve, even for somebody like me who had a taste of it before buying during the open beta. As a team based FPS with MOBA inspired elements (the game is not a full MOBA itself) Battleborn is all about choosing your battles, staying with team mates, avoiding death at all costs (death is punished in this game with increasingly longer respawn timers), and always remaining aware of the AI controlled minions (ignore these little guys and you will lose every game even if have been steam rolling the enemy team in kills).

The game comes with both a PvP mode and a PvE campaign. For me personally this is very nice because if I get tired of competitive PvP matches, I just switch over to the PvE and have fun blowing ♥♥♥♥ up for a while (while making sure to keep an eye on the objectives of course, these missions to have some challenge to them).
The missions of the PvP are not made to be played in a specific order besides doing the first 7 before the final mission against Rendain (In normal difficulty this is a seperate mission, but in advanced it gets mixed into the usual voting selection mentioned above) and as a result they do not have an over arching story but rather just the story of the mission itself.
Also I should mention that the PvE missions are VERY full of Gearbox style humor, so just be prepared for that. They basically went full on silly and ridiculous for the writing on this one.

While some people are turned off by progression systems, I personally find them a fun little bit of extra challenge, but I will say that for any worrying, unlocking the characters is not hard at all. And in case you do somehow have trouble, every character has two methods they can be unlocked by, the second being profile level. So even the characters who can be unlock by completely the advanced story mode and such can alternatively just be unlocked by inceasing your command rank which happens no matter what you play.

The progression system, aside from unlocking characters, is also involved in unlocking mutations" for each character's helix tree. All this means is that as you play a character
date: you unlock extra options to pick from as you level your character up each game (at the start of every PvE or PvP match you are at level 1). These mutations are often very useful
recommended: but they often won't redefine how you play a character but instead just give you another very useful option when playing. Also there will still likely be plenty of situations where you will choose one of the original two choices rather than the new mutation.\n\nAnother important topic to touch on is the gear system. As you play you will eventually begin to collect gear which can be activated in matches with the in-match currency of shards. This gear will provide stat bonuses to your character
hoursPlayed: and later legendary quality gear can even give special unique effects. However the power of a gear piece is always balanced by the number of shards you must gather and then spend in order to activate it. In fact
voteText: walking into PvP with a loadout full of three legendary pieces of gear is often a very bad idea because you likely won't be able to collect enough shards before the match ends to even activate all of them (additionally you will likely also avoid using the buildables situated throughout each map which tend to be very important to victory). Additionally
helpfulPercent: it is impossible to activate pricier gear right off the bat in PvP because giant shards don't spawn until a few minutes in (and even then you have the enemy team to compete with when it comes to breaking and gathering them).\n\nI do feel like I should touch on some issues you have likely seen in other reviews and let you know which ones are no longer an issue as of the time of this review. First of all
votesHelpful: the incursion mode exploit involving snipers on the map Overgrowth is no more. Second
votesTotal: the 5 minute prologue cutscene can be skipped if you do not wish to watch it. Third
votesFunny: after her third wave of nerfs
commentsCount: Galilea is no longer overpowered and can no longer 1v1 everyone and win (and in case you did not hear Ambra ceased being a problem quite some ago).\nI will admit that the game can certainly still use more optimization
column16: though they are gradually working on and improving that. And finally the match making is not completely unbalanced
column17: though when you are first starting out and the system does not have any data on you
column18: yes it can tend to put you in somewhat onesided matches. But I can personally say that this definitely changes once you have a collection of matches completed
column19: as I very rarely find myself in matches that feel one-sided in terms of player skill."

reviewText:
Battleborn is unique and edgy and I appreciate that a lot. It still needs some polishing, but it is already a good game.

Many reviews complain about the long queue times. I cannot agree with that. I play in EU and never had any problems. My queue times are mostly from 1-5 minutes in every game mode. Every story mode (normal and advanced) goes up quick and every PvP mode as well.

The only annoying thing to me is those people just leaving the game. This is a minor complaint I have and I think Gearbox should adress this. There is no penalty so as soon as people do not get the Battleborn they want or not the map they want, some of them leave. This is somewhat a homemade problem, because I do not think the implementation of a random map selection of only three which are then voted works well, because ... people tend to be selfish in PUGs. But so far this is my only real complaint about the game. But then again I also notices some really friendly and helpful people. When you ask about people helping you with your lore unlocks most people are going to help you.

At first I thought the explosion of visual effects on the screen would be distracting when watching Let's Plays on YouTube. But I was wrong. Yes, I do not always see everything, but it is much less difficult when you play it yourself. All in all I was able to deal with all the visual effects on the screen and it even adds to the badass action you are diving into.

Some complaints are about the matchmaking which I cannot agree upon. The command level rank does not equal skill. There are level 100 player who still do not play objectives in the game or cannot play with specific battleborns. The only problems with this is that people already give up when they see a high rank level in the enemy team. This is the problem. Not the matchmaking. Gearbox should make the command ranks invisible. It does not matter for the matchmaking or the matches. Even with a command level of 100 it may be my first time playing a battleborn or even with command level 5 this might be a battleborn I feel familiar with, because it uses game mechanics I prefer in other games as well.

That being said, what draws me to Battleborn mostly? I am a huge Dawngate fan. Yes, that is the MOBA that was killed by EA, because it did not make enough money in the Beta (sic!). Battleborn feels a little like it to me. Some of it’s modes got MOBA elements, but first and foremost: Battleborn has got awesome and unique character background and lore.

Battleborn got me immersed into the universe and it does it all within the game. I do not have to rely on out of game ressources. Battleborn has single player campagin which narrates the story and the setting. All characters got lore challenges to unlock tidbits of background on them. This feels more natural and more satisfying to me than in other games. Yet they also have a comic on their website which made me squeal, because Dawngate had an extra comic series as well. So it reminds me a lot of it.

While playing Battleborn everything in the game feels like I get to play the lore as well. For Battleborn the setting fits with all the things you are playing in game. All those characters from different factions are even supposed to fight sometimes on the own team. So all the bickering and remarks in game feel natural. This is why the immersion in Battleborn works so well. Battleborn hit me on the spot of immersion way better because of all this.

I like how the game merges the lore and the game modes. This is done pretty well and I love this postmodern apocalypse. It is rich with self-conscious irony and there are so many things which make me chuckle and after about 40 hours of gameplay I still discover some minor things which make me smile. This game feels like there was put a lot of heart and soul into it and I appreciate it for exactly this. This is a game which wants to be fun and does not take itself to serious in some moments, but in other immerses you into a pretty fun apocalypse with interesting characters.

And what about the combat? It is fun. I like FPS and this game does it pretty well. Each character feels so different to the point that I still do not know how to play some of them. This is one of the challenges of the game and I like that it takes this risk. You have to invest some time to learn those characters and some of them are not easy. Although you can pick some easier characters as well. But I have to admit that those are the least interesting to me. There is so much depth hidden in all the helix options, in the gear system and all those buildables.

It is not an easy game to get into, but once you give it a chance and invest that first few hours it is so rewarding and fun - at least to me.

May our battle never end ...

reviewText:
Having reached the 250 hour mark, I've decided it is high time for a review after having experienced a solid sum of this game.

-----

To start, Battleborn is a mix of content that is rewarding for you to mix PvE and PvP content. While one can purely participate in PvP content, you'll be missing out on some nice pieces of gear which gets used in both forms of content.

PvE:
Currently, we have access to 8 story mode missions and an additional solo Prologue to introduce you to the game.
Each one centers in on the progression of the story against the star-stealing Varelsi and Rendain's Jennerit army.

These missions take place in a variety of different environments, map layouts, and hosts a number of different enemy types.
Most objectives will involve escorting large sentires, who are more than capable of defending themselves at times, or the defense of a stationary objective.

The game's difficulty scales with how many players are on your team, so going in alone will be easier than going in with a 5-man group.
Difficulty can go higher by utilizing Advanced difficulty, which handles enemy damage/health/spawn patterns differently.
There is also Hardcore mode, which removes Extra Lives and making you play cautiously.

5 additional story mode missions will be added overtime through the season pass too.

----------
PvP: Currently we have 3 PvP modes and 2 maps per mode.
Capture: Three points exist on the map to be controlled by the teams, there is limited currency available on these maps and many people will use lower-ranked gear to compensate for this.

Incursion: Each team has two sentries that guard a part of their base. Teams are to push through enemy defenses and destroy the enemy sentry. Getting mercenaries to aid in your push is vital, along with appropriate timing and a good balance of offense/defense. There is often an abundance of currency available and you can use your best gear loadouts.

Meltdown: You must escort your minions to specific areas to sacrifice them, gaining favor with Minrec. This is a balance of protecting your own minions, while destroying the enemy minions before they reach their destination. Two lanes will exist, leading to teams needing to divide their forces appropriately to ensure both lanes are protected. Currency is also abundant here, allowing you to bring good loadouts.

Gearbox has already stated they will be releasing more maps and game modes in the future. They've revealed some concept art for map designs.

5 new heroes are being added over time, these heroes will be available to everyone, but must be unlocked.

We already have one added, Alani.

-------

Balancing:

Gearbox has handled balancing characters with a steady hand. They are careful not to fall into the hole like many other PvP games do, where they overnerf a character and destroy their viability. Instead, Gearbox makes adjustments over time and sees the community reaction, then adjusts further if they feel it is needed. This progressive balancing has made me greatly appreciate their methods, as one of my favorite characters was subject to this balance. Ambra is still as viable as ever and still remains very strong.

So if you're afraid a favorite character of yours will be subject to overzealous nerfs, do not fear. Gearbox has taken the right approach in how to balance.

--------

Matchmaking:
I'm seeing a lot of negativity over this, and I feel like it was unwarranted, because it is something that can and HAS been improved on.
Matchmaking utilizes an invisible ELO rating for players, but did not originally account for Command Rank(which only reflects how -LONG- you have played the game).
This led to people who are command rank 10, who have a somewhat unimpressive ELO getting paired with people of command rank 70 with similar ELO.

While this still sometimes occurs, it is rare that they are not equally skilled.
Matchmaking has seen quite a few improvements so far and it has done well for improving the quality of each match.
Premades now have a priority to be paired with other premades; preventing pubstomps" from being common place and instead putting you up against a team with equally reliable communication.

Matchmaking itself has improved as well
date: leading to more equally skilled teams in public matches. This has been great for me
recommended:
as I commonly queue alone or with a single friend.

------

Characters:
Gearbox did a superb job here
hoursPlayed: creating a wide array of characters with countless personality

reviewText: First off: Great game. Is it worth yuor 60 bucks? It's complicated. I got 25% off through greenman gaming website. I also like Moba style games, and borderlands. Will this game feel like borderlands....yes, but the story and replay value will be nothing like borderlands because they focus on the pvp gameplay. Story is charming, but not at the level of even the worst story missions in all borderland's games. Issues: no advance difficulty matchmacking...So you have to grind normal difficulty, or you have to have friends and create your own 5 man party, or go solo...upsetting to me. PVP is not my thing. I like it but I have to learn the maps and characters = time not playing, or playing and losing. I dont like to lose lol. So is it worth getting because it is still in the (sort of) universe of borderland... yes, but get it on sale. Do not pay full price. Is it fun? yes, for a time. Then you fall into a loop that smells like teen spirit for pve, and pvp is maybe not everyones cut of cake.
