reviewText:
Bare with me please. This is my first review of a game:

Battleborn, first and foremost, is a MOBA that attempts to be a shooter at the same time but fails at both. While it has it's fair share of strengths (most notably its signature Gearbox charm of a vibrant world and setting coupled with Borderlands brand humor) It's weaknesses far outweigh those strengths.

The best way for me to review this would be to cover each of its key points seperately. It's competetive multiplayer, Overview of game mechanics, and It's singleplayer/Co-op story mode.

1: The Game as a whole:
Battleborn's core controls and mechanics are pretty solid, easily feeling like they were built off of that of Borderlands meaning for an easy to adjust to playstyle for fans of Gearbox. However Gearbox delved into melee based combat for a first person shooter. A difficult act to manage and they fell short. (Borderlands allowed players to focus on melee, but at least those characters could resort to range when needed)

Now they did try, and had a good idea, They failed to see why that good intended idea fell short.  Too much happens on the screen, and if you want to play Melee (which is a large number of the 2 dozen character choices) You're going to have a bad time trying to follow what's happening. You can see everything your characters see, but that mean that often too much takes up the screen for you to reliably follow the action in front of you.  And while melee has a high damage output, this is only in a short burst against a single Target. This means that for the increased HP of enemies and the scaled up difficulty, you can't play melee unless you have a whole team to back you up.

2: Competetive Multiplayer:
Matchmaking is horrid. I am just going to state that first. But 20 minute wait times only to recieve an unbalanced team match up isn't truely a concern when compared to the rest.  The Competetive Multiplayer mode is where most the game's short comings come to light.

Battleborn has three Multiplayer games modes, with mediocre map selection.  As a MOBA, in order to play Battleborn well you need to think and strategize as you would LOL, Heros of the Storm, or Dota. However, Battleborn looks and feels like a shooter instead. As a result you get the worst of both worlds instead of one.  On the MOBA side.  Too much is going on during combat, and this makes it even harder to plan and strategize because given a first person perspective of their character, the Player looses sight of important things they may see in any other Top down MOBA. Plus in a MOBA, players  often have to focus on how much damage one combo or maneuver will do. but Given the FPS aspects, that damage is no longer guaranteed. as it is very easy to miss a shot, rendering your MOBA stratgies nearly worthless.

If you move to the shooter side though, The MOBA aspects ruin it just as shooter concepts  ruined the MOBA side.  A large portion of shooters are fast paced action, and Your attacks, since they have a chance to miss given your skill level, should hold weight when you land them. But instead in the typical MOBA Fashion, there are no true rapid kills. MY own experience would serve as a great example.

I am an avid sniper, I have great aim and in Battleborn I am proud to say I rarely miss critical hit points. and the whole satisfaction of a sniper, is to stay back, and get one kill per shot fired. but thanks to Battleborn's MOBA side, my Rifle can't take anyone down in one shot, let alone several in most occassions. This means that all my sniper skills go to waste, and hold no weight in the tide of battle. This fact held true for several of the other characters I played as. It may play like a shooter, but your skills mean almost nothing.

3: Single Player/Co-op story mode
The story mode is disappointing.  While it is the most fun aspect of the game, and I enjoy playing it with friends, it is still weak thanks to the rest of the game's shortcomings. The environments and maps are nice to look at, and I found myself enjoying mowing down the... less than varied enemy types. in the first 7 missions, each boss was different to enough of a degree that they felt fresh each time.  None of the missions felt too long  but some did feel they would get tedious seeing as they kept recycling many of the same elements over and over again.  However, the 8th mission was disappointing.  they give you a rather unforgiving time limit that is tough to make. and then the final boss is a cop out.

Rather than give an interesting fight,  The battle just recycles the other 7 bosses from the game, and it becomes long and  annoying rather than fun. because what made each boss interesting becomes a painstakingly annoying  task when its paired with another boss with a similar concern. and the bosses were made tougher than their previous versions, making it even more frustrating.

Back to the story, The characters all have their quirks, and the game has it's fair share of good humor. the plot falls short because Gearbox didn't really put much effort past the setting.  Each mission tries to pass as part of a bigger story, but it doesn't feel that way.  There is no timeline so missions can be done out of order, as you beat each one, you don't feel as if you have made progress" in the story. leaving that aspect of the game unfullfilling.


Now... I think I covered everything I wanted to say
date: and I hope people find this useful. forgive my poor structure and the like

as I said this is my first review for a game I had really expected more out of.

reviewText:
Do not overlook this game because you think it's like Overwatch. It is not!

Battleborn is Dota meets FPS in terms of game play not just by having heroes instead of classes. It is rough around the edges, and certainly has its problems, but it is a refreshingly different game play from your classic team based FPS by focusing very much on coordinated objective centered game play in a variety of Moba inspired game modes.

Gearbox have already announced that they're currently internally playtesting a variety of new maps and are planning on adding at least one more multiplayer game mode, ranked matchmaking, better spectating and a whole bunch of other stuff.

Yes, it is not as polished as the other big upcoming hero shooter"
date: yes it's not as amazing as it could be (and should be) but at the moment Battleborn offers FPS game play you won't find anywhere else and it does so in a solid and enjoyable fashion (at least for me as an FPS fan and someone who always liked the tactical depth of Mobas but never could get into them) and is promising to get better in the future."

reviewText:
Battleborn is a fresh and incredibly well polished fusion of popular genres; the first person shooter, MOBA, and a smattering of RPG elements, all lovingly enshrined in the hyper slick aesthetic we've come to love from the people that created the Borderlands franchise.

Right from the jump, with its Samurai Champloo-esque prologue animation with killer track by Deltron 3030 (!), the game oozes style, polish, and love from its development team.

The game is easy to jump into and start mowing down enemies, but lurking underneath the surface of the Serious Sam-esque waves of pain mission syle is a complex and highly customizable system of talents and items that is bound to see extensive min/maxing from the community, leading to exciting and fresh takes on the various character offerings for months to come.

The PVP is addictive, and when the matchmaking nails the skill levels, you're in for a tense and fierce battle for victory that'll go to the wire. All of the online versus modes are unique twists on the MOBA formula that breathe life into the essentially unchanged Warcraft 3 map, Meltdown being my particular favorite.

The ticket price is high, at $60, but I already feel like I've gotten my money's worth, and with enough support from Gearbox, Battleborn will be a comfortable well played favorite for years to come.

reviewText: I am a big fan of gearbox, and their ability to fuse genres together to take the best of both. Battleborn is an FBS/MOBA hybrid--it takes twitch shooting SKILLS and mechanics from the world of competitive FPS games, and takes battle TACTICS and long-term planning from the MOBA genre. I'll explain why I like these especially and why they come together to make a great competitive game.\n\nBut first, let's talk about what you get. Unlike other multiplayer games, you don't even have to play multiplayer to get a full game" experience. Battleborn has 8 story missions
recommended: which last about 30-40 minutes. This means the game is completed in about 4 to 6 hours if you're quick. It doesn't sound like too much
hoursPlayed: but there are 25 characters to play as (with 5 more coming as free DLC over the next few months)
voteText: which gives HUGE replay value
helpfulPercent: in my opinion. Several of these characters have to be unlocked as you progres through the game
votesHelpful: but I never found this to be a huge problem. I really enjoy the Story mode
votesTotal: and have put a ton of time into it. $60 is a bit steep for JUST the story experience
votesFunny: but for me it's worth it. To others it might not be.\n\nHowever
commentsCount: you ALSO get the entire multiplayer experience as well
column16: which is why I think Battleborn is such a great value. And it's a very unique multiplayer experience at that.\n\nCOD/other "arena" shooters focus on kills. There can be other objectives
column17: but generally the team with more kills is going to win no matter what. Class-based shooters like TF2 help remedy this by provide roles for characters to fill
column18: such as healing and logistics in the Medic and Engineer classes. This lets players contribute without having the best deathmatch skills.\n\nIn battleborn
column19: it's never about kills. The primary objective is minions; if you're not taking out minions
column20: then you're not contributing to your team. Killing minions sounds dull at first for an FPS
column21: but the fact that the enemy team is also there adds a huge amount of strategy. You can rush into the opponent's base and kill two of their teammates
column22: and in the process be killed yourself. But by overextending you might have allowed the enemy minions the cross over your lines; now your team is at a disadvantage. Minions are the central game mechanic
column23: but PvP combat is still important. Once a player fight has begun then your FPS skills come into play
column24: which is something I dislike about other MOBAs--they don't seem skill-based
column25: to me.\n\nBut there's other factors about the combat to consider too. You need to manage resources
column26: and build turrets to keep your defenses up. This lets players without FPS skills contribute to the team as well. You might have a 1-12 KDR
column27: but you can still be the most important player on your team. Both of these genres have been blended together to create something really original. Your knowledge of battlefield strategy will tell you WHEN to push
column28: and your FPS skills will help you win the push when it happens.\n\nI haven't personally had experience with it
column29: but there have been reports of graphical problems on AMD cards. Matchmaking can also be a bit of a problem
column30: though
column31: depending on time of day and how many players there are. In my opinion
column32: it's worth it for the matches
column33: and gearbox has been very open about continued support for improving matchmaking and performance as the game goes on."

reviewText:
I'm not going to lie. This game has a very Borderlands/Anthony Burch-tier humor style in its writing, and at some points it can be grating. And yet at other points, it can be fun and fitting. I consider it its lowest point in terms of story, which is sad considering the amount of effort Gearbox goes to force its humor in your face.

There, now that my one major quirk with the game is taken care of; lets get on with the good parts.

Hero Selection:
Pretty damned amazing. You start off with a sizeable roster that is pretty varied in roles. Almost feels moba-ish, in which there's support, tanks, and DPS. Many of the characters in the game need to be unlocked, not from a paywall but from an achievement/challenge perspective. Usually it's pretty simple: Level your account to hit the rank needed to play the character, or do various secondary challenges (Kill 50 players, get Silver medals on all story missions, play five times as one faction) in order to unlock them.

PVE:
Story writing aside, I have quite a few complaints with how the mission roulette is set. You either have to play with a band of four people you know in order to select a mission you need to complete (Saboteur or Heliophage come to mind), or you need to solo queue and hope one of the three randomized missions that pops up is one of the few you need.
Thankfully Gearbox countered this by letting you play a private session where you're able to select which story mission to progress from, where you're gated to the highest level mission you've completed. As of this review, I have still yet to complete Saboteur and Heliophage because I have no friends (kill me fam).

PVP:
What an absolute cluster♥♥♥♥. This is where class balance is shown to not have been a major consideration in Gearbox's head. Many heros perform underwhelmingly in PVP, while others can pretty much solo every class without a challenge.
And what PVP modes they do have, they don't have a really intrinsic guide on what the bloody Hell you're supposed to be doing. Sure they give that mini-tutorial at the start of the match, but all the intricacies of the map are just left to the players best guess.
Of all the PVP matches I've played, it's usually been either an hour long standoff in the middle of the map because their healers are just blatantly keeping everyone topped up forever, or its an absolute stomp because one team is missing a healer or tank.
Solution: Buff everyone.

TL;DR: The game has a wide selection of heroes to play, a decent loot system, a subpar PVE storyline, and absolutely craptastic PVP. Still a lot of persistent bugs and glitches that need to be ironed out as well as a major rebalancing of PVP. It is indeed still one of Gearbox's better releases if compared to Borderlands or (god's sake) Aliens: Colonial Marines.
A good note is that it's less 'meme-y' than Borderlands, if that kind of humor makes you cringe.

reviewText:
Battleborn Multiplayer Gameplay Review
This will only be a multiplayer gameplay review. I have not completed the story, so I can not give a full review on it. However, the story definately deserves a 10/10 specifically for originality.

Multiplayer Rating: 8.5/10

Pros

Excellent character design
Exclusive maps to each game mode
Good combat mechanics (See recommendations and cons)
Nice visuals for the genre (See recommendations)
Unique and fun building mechanic
Minions are spot-on
Cons

The game still feels like it's in the Beta stage (See summary)
Good communication requires a headset (See recommendations)
Often times, combat will feel like a controller is necessary (See recommendations)
Regardless of accessories being being personally recommended, the game still feels more comfortable on PC rather than console
Recommendations

This is specifically aimed at the dev team for Battleborn and included for players' imaginations.

Include a tactical map for objective planning and ping focused communication
Skills/Spells are often much too flashy to a point where damage-only abilities double as a blinding CC
The chatbox feels forced into the game as a third-party UI; find a way for it to blend better and be more accessible
As the combat is focused on FPS mechanics, it is hard to react as quickly as a controller user; and with the visuals of blinding abilities, this can simply be fixed by adding a Third-Person camera option to better optimize combat
Overall, the multiplayer still feels like it's in the beta stage. There are so many things that can be done to improve the player's experience other than the balancing of heroes; which quite frankly, will probably need updates pretty frequently if Gearbox decides to take the 'Unbalanced Balance' approach. I definately do not ever want to see that idea incorporated, but with the MOBA genre, it is an extremely popular trend. Just don't get your hopes up.

I have also taken into consideration that this game is still new and will probably be in for an aging developmental process that MOBA gamers are familiar with; hence, the positive recommendation.

Do not be afraid to get your hands on Battleborn so soon. It will take time, but I'm confident in Gearbox's ability to deliver an outstanding multiplayer game. If you are afraid to spend the $60 - $75, just give this game some time to grow. Come back in a couple months to catch up with its improvements so you can make your decision then.

reviewText: Battleborn was almost a sort of impulse buy for me.  I enjoyed the lore that the Borderlands games set up, despite not playing them, and while I wanted to save money by buying the cheaper Borderlands games, it was at that very moment that Battleborn was released.  I found some people who were enjoying the game, and the promise of PVE was what sold it for me, hands down.  Other games such as Team Fortress 2 tend to require you to have many, many people to play with, with either queues or servers that have random, ever changing rules.  Even the PVE in those games tend to require upwards of 5-7 people to complete, especially for those who were just playing to have fun.\n\nAs such, Battleborn quickly became a favorite for me.  I play PVP when I'm in a team of three or four friends, and when I'm playing alone, I queue up for PVE.  On normal difficulty in PVE, I can group up with only one or two random people, and even without communication, I've learned how each map works enough to get through without too much trouble.  It's become incredibly fun for me, despite me only having an hour or two a day to play on weekdays.  The PVE stories might not be the most amazing novels in the world, but Gearbox has dialed back the memes and brought us a slightly darker story that seems lighter from the fact that every character is a little crazy fun in their own way.  Every one of the 25 characters has two or three dimensions to them, usually displayed through their lore" that is unlocked mostly through just playing the game.  Some are harder to get than others
date: but it is really much fun to do them as a goal to work towards as you play
recommended: rather than focusing solely on collecting them as quickly as possible.\n\nThere are three different PVP modes to play

reviewText: What a surprisingly awesome gem this game is! This is a great and super colorful first-person MOBA meets Borderlands type of game. It has a fantastic cast of crazy and unique characters, great writing, and fun gameplay and abilities. No matter what you've heard, this is not a cheap and lame rip-off of Overwatch. Overwatch is a game that plays like Call of Duty with abilites like a MOBA. This is an actual MOBA like game (at least in it's gameplay and feel). When you play this, you must keep in mind that this is not just a FPS game, it is like a MOBA and needs to be treated as such. If you like the humor from Borderlands, you will LOVE this game since there is a huge amount of that here too. It has a prologue mission and eight story missions to complete on normal or advanced. And if you think advanced is just a little tougher, I will let you know from just beating the final level on advanced that it is super tough and brutal. It took a full party of five of us an hour to beat the last level on advanced. It's rough and punishing. Overall, a fantastic game with fun multiplayer as well with creative modes that will only get better as time goes with more updates and patches. Also, they said that all the other modes and maps and the remaining five extra add-on characters will be free to all players. reviewText: What a surprisingly awesome gem this game is! This is a great and super colorful first-person MOBA meets Borderlands type of game. It has a fantastic cast of crazy and unique characters, great writing, and fun gameplay and abilities. No matter what you've heard, this is not a cheap and lame rip-off of Overwatch. Overwatch is a game that plays like Call of Duty with abilites like a MOBA. This is an actual MOBA like game (at least in it's gameplay and feel). When you play this, you must keep in mind that this is not just a FPS game, it is like a MOBA and needs to be treated as such. If you like the humor from Borderlands, you will LOVE this game since there is a huge amount of that here too. It has a prologue mission and eight story missions to complete on normal or advanced. And if you think advanced is just a little tougher, I will let you know from just beating the final level on advanced that it is super tough and brutal. It took a full party of five of us an hour to beat the last level on advanced. It's rough and punishing. Overall, a fantastic game with fun multiplayer as well with creative modes that will only get better as time goes with more updates and patches. Also, they said that all the other modes and maps and the remaining five extra add-on characters will be free to all players. I love it and I think more people need to know about this amazing gem that due to Overwatch's publicity and advertising has gotten swept under the rug a bit. Go buy it now! 10/10 VERY HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

reviewText:
Very addictive. Has voice in the games. UI is clean. Key binds are confusing, but once you find what is what it's simple enough. Unlocking the characters, thier lore, skins and taunts makes doing things a certain way feel fun and gives you a challenge. Voices are unique compared to other characters being played and your surroundings. The characters interact with each other in unique ways which makes the game funny. The sense of humour in the game is the same as Borderlands, so expect sarcastic wit. Voices are also recognizable from the Borderlands series (Orendi - Tiny Tina, Benedict - Scooter, etc. etc.). Art style is clean and unique also (I'm using unique a lot haha!). Each character feels different and bring something to the table, but each also has thier own limitations.

Storyline is easily repeatable, but you will need a group for the harder missions or at least a group that can communicate. This game is definitely better with friends, unless you're just PVPing. Story mode, you will want to find people to try and finish them all.

PVP is fun and challenging. Very limited on maps and modes, 3 modes - each with having 2 maps, but that doesn't bother me much. Each mode is vastly different though which gives you your own choice of what you want to do. MOBA style, escort style and capture points. Each feels different and requires different strategies which is nice.

Overall a good game. Needs a bit more maps and overall content, but the amount of characters out is nice. Also, the company keeps updates churning out as players request certain things. They listen to their consumers, which is a big plus (such as with the prologue not being replayable).

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game. I got a lot of fun out of Smite and this looked like a great FPS version of that with the added bonus of Borderlands-style art and humor.

But this game is a waste of money. The PvE can be enjoyable the first or second time through but after that, it is a complete snorefest. And it's pretty much required for PvP because it's the best way to get gear. Just buy gear packs with the in-game currency, you say? Well in one of the most inane decisions of game development history, the better packs (with a higher chance for good gear) are LOCKED BEHIND A LEVEL REQUIREMENT. That makes no sense at all. I've got like 20k credits that I just won't spend because I don't have the gear packs unlocked that have high chances of epic/legendary gear.

The PvP is a complete joke. It's not the mechanics of it that suck, but the realization of the game. The playerbase on PC is abysmal, which results in terrible matchmaking experiences. You'll be a fresh player with little going on for you going against people with 150+ hours logged. These people have better gear than you do. These people have all of their helix mutations unlocked. And they have experience playing the game. It isn't fun. In the 10 hours or so of PvP I've played, I have had exactly ONE fair match. Otherwise it is just one team stomping the other and then an 8-10 minute surrender.

Balance is ♥♥♥♥. Some heroes are just completely faceroll and those are often the heroes being picked by those people with 150+ hours. They just ♥♥♥♥ all over the new players and the match is completely ruined. You can't even just pick those heroes and be on an equal field because again, you won't have the good gear for them and you won't have the helix choices unlocked. So you'll just be a lesser version and you'll still get beat out.

This game will die. It's a shame but there's too much bad to save it because the playerbase is going to quickly atrophy to the point where good match making will be impossible. Save your money and pass on this one.

reviewText: Battleborn is a fun mix of MOBA and Borderlands. It's great for people who don't really enjoy the more traditional MOBA titles available. The singleplayer is fun and interesting, combining the MOBA style of starting fresh of abilities every match or mission with the fun shooting style of Borderlands and Borderlands 2. I highly recommend this game to anyone whom enjoys MOBAs, or enjoyed the Borderlands series but is looking for something somewhat similar with new mechanics.\n\nThe campaign is fun both solo and co-op. It has enough interesting characters to hold your interest. It's story is told very much like Borderlands 2, with someone talking in your ear most of the time. It has Borderlands-esque boss intros with a freeze-frame and title card. The loot in the game has been changed significantly from any BL title, now coming in Packs." You open these to create a loadout of three gear pieces which you can then purchase using "shards" once in a mission or multiplayer match. This fits the multiplayer focus of the game
date: and makes it fun to plan your purchases to be more effective throughout the mission.\n\nThe multiplayer is the real gem of the game. It's phenomenal. It does everything right. With a whopping 25 "Heroes" to choose from
recommended: it won't be hard to find something new to try if you tire of one hero. Three gamemodes
hoursPlayed: each with two maps makes for a variety of fun to be had. Incursion
voteText: which is the most MOBA-like of the game modes is super fun and satisfying when played with a good team. You must push with your minion waves to destroy the two Sentry-Bots in the enemy's base before they do the same to you. In Meltdown you must send your minions to be sacrificed

It's the only gamemode I have yet to play. You must defend your points while capturing the enemy's. Fairly self explainatory.\n\nOverall
votesHelpful: I really enjoy this game so far and highly recommend it to anyone thinking about picking up a good multiplayer game that you can get competitive with or just chill out and play some campaign missions."

reviewText:
Can't recommend this game in the current state its in, it needs a lot of work before it's even on par with other F2P competitive mobas.

Strange or bad design decisions abound in this game including but not limited to the following:

General Subjective
- Terribly boring single player/co-op missions (essential for progression and receiving gear)
- Movement skills are clunky (feels as if you have 200 or so ping at all times)
- Guns feel clunky and inaccurate even when they should be hitting
- Damage and TTK seems way too low
- Cluttered UI

General Objective
- Friendly minions Body block, which would be okay, but you can't jump over the large camp summons and they can box you out of a retreat)
- Relating to the point above, the two MOBA maps are designed around tiny chokepoints
- Non exsistant match making (lvl 1-10's get matched versus lvl 60-100's almost every game)
- Single player/ co-op mobs are bullet sponges and were clearly not balanced for Melee or AOE characters (most require headshots only to kill in under 30 seconds)
- After the first objective (tower) is killed, creeps turn into superminions causing the winning team to snowball too hard
- Miko's ability to sprint while healing
- Marquis and Toby Exploit for Overgrowth still not fixed (can snipe the enemy objective from their own base)
- Marquis view model bug (can peek over cover and shoot safely, head cannot be seen or shot)
- Deande's clone has same color health bar, (for teammates) making it hard for your own team to tell which is which
- Enemy name plates bug out for characters like Pheobe, making them almost invisible unless you're looking at the minimap (mostly a problem with screen clutter and FOV)

FOV
- Poor FOV for most characters (affects melee mostly)
- Poor View models for most characters (severely affects melee)
- Unnecessary screen shake on melee characters like Kelvin (making them nausiating to play)
- Pheobe's basic attacks flash on screen (only for her), making them hard to stomach for an entire match (seizure inducing)

Hilarious
-FOV - The community responds to these FOV issues by suggesting melee has to look at their mini map rather than their screen while fighting in order to see/kill enemies.

- Sniper exploit on Overgrowth (Marquis and Toby) - Community refuses to acknowledge this is an issue (many claim it's fine), and thus it hasnt been fixed in the last two patches.

- Currently there is a thread on the battleborn reddit asking players to recommend the game to change it's rating from Mixed" to "Mostly Positive"

- How useless Wiskey Foxtrot is in versus multiplayer because of the clunky shooting.

- This game is a clear step back in quality and polish from Gearbox's previous games (Borderlands 2 and Pre-Sequel) in almost every aspect: Character design
hoursPlayed: character builds
voteText: player gearing
helpfulPercent: weapon and view models
votesHelpful: FOV
votesTotal: Gun and movement feel
votesFunny: Story and writing
commentsCount: and single player/ co-op campaign."

WOW!!!! First off I want to review both the campaign and the multiplayer. The campaign is really amazing. I am not going to give anything away let’s just say if you like borderlands humor, art style then you will enjoy the campaign. The way you level up your character and can play multiple characters adds the replay value of some of the levels, all the characters that I have played so far have very different play styles which adds to that replay value. They claimed that no character plays the same which I would have to say so far that is absolutely right. Graphics are amazing, mechanics are very smooth like a game should be. And the story is intriguing. I don’t want to give anything else away about the campaign. Now for the multiplayer let me say FINALLY this is a moba game that I can actually really enjoy. They did such an amazing job mixing moba and fps games. The multiplayer is really fun. People that don’t enjoy the moba style I still recommend this game; I think that you would be able to enjoy this style of multiplayer. Plus, even if you don’t absolutely love the multiplayer the campaign missions are coop so you can still play the missions with friends which I would say the game is still worth picking up. The people that created borderlands made this. If you like their games, you will enjoy this. Now back to the multiplayer for people that love moba, or think moba isn’t bad you will love this game I believe. I preordered this and overwatch, and I have a feeling that these games are going to hurt the Heroes of the Storm, and the League of legends, and Dota 2 crowds if those gamers have always wished that they could take their character into first person. Playing in first person makes this fps moba game so much more immersive. I feel like this game will be one I spend a lot of time playing. Peace and Cheers fellow gamers.

And after it you've got balanced versus high-level team that dominates yours easily and your whole team of low-levels just leaves after 5 minutes of this humiliation and you must wait about 30 minutes again to repeat last step.
And according to SteamSpy the concurrent audience getting smaller day by day, which tells that after few weeks it finally reaches close-to-zero value.
I am very disappointed with this shameful waste of money.

reviewText:
This is an extremely fun, fast, class based shooter.
FPS and/or MOBA fans should defanitely check this out.

Pros:
- Good campaign with co-op mode and  varying difficulties, which adds good replay value.
- SOLID voice acting all around and great humour.
- Each hero feels unique and refreshing in his/her playstyle.
- The campaign feels like a mix of Borderlands and Guild wars 2.
- Balanced loot system
- No microtransactions (yet)

Cons:
- PVP matchmaking seems non-existant. As someone who solo ques , constantly running into premades is very annoying.
-  You get almost little to no experience when doing (and winning) PVP as compared to PVE. This will deter people who want to solely focus on PVP since leveling their account/hero will be absmally slow.
- Too many people (including me) having FPS drop issues.
- The games does very little to expain most of the PVP and map mechanics, making it harder for newer players.
- Menu UI - You cannot search or sort heroes based on class among other things.
- When in the heat of battle, things feel like a huge cluster f**k on-screen


Overall, this feels like a solid game and is extremely fun when playing with friends. However, Gearbox needs to do A LOT to polish and balance the PVP in order to make the player-base grow.

8/10

reviewText:
I spent a fair amount of time playing this game. I ENJOYED PLAYING THIS GAME! IT IS A FUN EXPERIENCE

The MOBA - FPS gameplay is fun! The character designs are awesome. The humor in the game is what you'd expect from Borderlands, not that its a bad thing. Playing with friends is, of course, a far better experience, but regardless, its still fun to play with strangers.

Unfortunately, the way things are going for Battleborn, I can't recommend it. On the first few weeks of playing, there were already issues with connectivity. Oceania players have been having troubles with connecting to a game, with wait times lasting as long as 15 - 20 minutes, and when they do get put into a game, the match ends up being very unbalanced with players being teamed up with others that are either complete beginners or long playing veterans.

There have also been issues regarding performance. Certain levels in the game can even strain the highest performing gaming rigs. This results in players choosing certain levels in PVP. If this isn't an issue for you then fine, but playing on the same levels time and time again for the sake of keeping a solid frame rate can get a bit tedious. Can't enjoy a nice juicy steak if that's all you're ever gonna eat. Sometimes you want a cheeseburger... or something. Whatever, bad example.

I'm sure that theese issues will be solved in future patches.

With the game going for 40% off after only being out for 3 WEEKS, I'd say buy it, but at full price, it just isn't worth it.
If you are thinking about buying this game, buy it during a sale. Otherwise, set aside Battleborn and buy O-...ther games that are well worth their full price.

voteText: 11 of 19 people (58%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
6 minute UNSKIPPABLE cutscene which is the only way to test settings when you first get the game. ♥♥♥♥ YOU!

- Game performance/optimization is the worst of any full price, online only title this year. It's beyond me how you can fail this hard when you use Unreal already. The framerate fluctuates between 120/30 on a Titan X, no matter the settings, same goes for a 750. Its simply a joke.

- The art style might be a matter of taste the complete over saturation of effects and colors is not. It's hard to see anything but a jumbled mess of color vomit for what feels like  50%+ of the game.

- Collision detection is also a joke, you get stuck on the tiniest pebble or the most common corner on any map. Some hero models are obnoxiously large and friendly players block you just as often as not.

- Hero balance is another matter. Its not as broken as the rest of the game but it's not in a ready to release state.

- Maps are exploitable by certain champions. And the moba like game mode feels like no one ever played it pre release. Pushing is close to impossible (unless you have really bad opponents) and games usually end after the timer runs out.

- Matchmacking is a joke. I have seen streams where 5 streamers with account levels ranging from 3 to 25 get matched against teams of professional players THREE TIMES IN A ROW.
For me I haven’t played an enjoyable game yet it's always a complete stomp and games almost always end in an early FF. The only question is whether you stomp or get stomped.

To top it off with a cherry, should you (and every friend you played with) be unlucky" enough to play during a server restart/shutdown you will get a useless "inventory timeout" message and won't be able to start a new game or sign into your account again until you account times out.

They have 5 DLCs planned already on top of a full AAA price. While things like OW go for 40 bucks FLAT and Paladins will be simply free by HiRez.
This game is not worth full price

reviewText:
Finally started to patch out the game.

The game itself is pretty good:
Solid gameplay (Has an arcady/fast paced feel to it)
Colourful stylish graphics
Badass animations
Great voice actors (Though feels like they over-doing it at times)
Great humour (Very gearbox-ish)
A full campaign: Solo and/or co-op (up to 5 players)
PvP 5 v 5 Moba, Goes into 3 game modes: Capture point, Meltdown (Minion escort to enemy tower) and Incursion (Attack and defend bases)
Lot of unique and different characters with their own personalities and abilities
Loot system that enhances different stats (some can give downsides and/or higher cost)
Not pay to win (Nothing to buy with real money so you only have to play to get everything)
There are some issues though.

Story/campaign!
While this game has campaign, it just doesn't feel important, infact, feels tacked on.
I expected better story telling from gearbox but about half feels like filler.
There are many sections where you have to protect or escort stuff.
Difficulty spikes at the end.
It's good to try out heroes though or if you're into score attack".

Loot!
While there is lot of loot with random stats...it's not really interesting
date:
bunch of "stickers" that give stat boosts.

It's online only!
Yeah
recommended:
even for campaign...nothing you can do about it.

Music!
It has it's moments...but very forgettable.

PvP!
Announcer sometimes say who is summoned or base is being attacked etc.
hoursPlayed: you can still be rather clueless if you won't look at the map non-stop. Also

reviewText:
It's probably a great game for you if you love first person shooter MOBAs. If you're MOBA-curious, this game is not gonna make you fall in love with the genre.

Pros:
+It's beautiful. Especially the characters are stunning. They all have fantastic details, great personalities and charming banter. It's like a comedy version of Borderlands, with loony AIs, gentleman robots and space elves.
+The co-op campaign is rather fun (if short).
+The intro video and cut scenes are cartoonish and great fun to watch.

Cons:
-It's a game about 1) PVP - using your three abilities to punish the opposing players in three game modes 2) PvE - Using your three abilities to beat a rather easy coop campaign with.. six stages? Five? You can complete them all in 3 hours and from then on it's just repetition.
-Matchmaking is random. Utterly random. You can end up with five lvl 2 teammates trying to kill all lvl30+ opponents. It's oh so random. Oh, and if someone decides to flee your lowbie team before the match starts, then, well, that's YOUR problem.
-This might be just me, but I sort of resent the fact that the single player campaign has NOTHING to do with the PvP. The single player campaign is campy but fun story about freeing heroes and saving the last remnants of the universe. And then you... start killing those heroes you just saved in a really weird arena setting where you have to hold flags or sacrifice robots? It's as if you played through the first chapter of Borderlands and then suddely the game turned into an arena shooter.

Nah, I call humbug. If you KNOW that're going to love this game, then you probably already own it (and love it). If you find yourself sitting on the fence, just remain there. Don't buy this.

reviewText:
Product received for free

PvP - Half the character roster is broken, so expect to see the same group of 6 or so heroes every game. Matchmaking is incredibly bad, matching level 90+ players against people less than level 10.  There's no real penalty for leaving matches other than wait time to queue again.

PvE - The campaign isn't really engaging and grinding it solo isn't worth the time. The way the co-op system works means you can't queue for specific missions (minor complaint but still worth mentioning).

If you still want it wait for a sale. Even with all the content the game currently has, it's not worth the full retail price. Otherwise, avoid it like the plague.

date: especially when you play with friends. I'm "Not Recommending" it because there are way too many glaring issues that make the price simply ridiculous. Alright? On with the review.\n\nBattleborn is a Hero Shooter where you pick one of many characters
recommended: each with their own role to the team. There are various forms to play (which I'll go over each indivdually soon):\nPvP:\n-Meltdown; where you escort minions to the enemy base
hoursPlayed: trying to score more points before your opponent to reach a goal or have more points at time out.\n-Incursion: you push into enemy territory to destroy their Sentry Robots.\n-Capture Zones: Multiple capture areas appear
voteText: and you must control them to gain points
helpfulPercent:
and first team to reach enough points wins.

with multiple chapters going across the story.


In terms of raw gameplay

but other than some clunky kits character kits generally just make sense.

column23: but I find that unless you kill the opponents within a short time frame of your own dying
column24: if you lose your outer robot
column25: you lose all map control. This is due to a few reasons: First you lose the easy access to money and buildings. Two
column26: you can buy out opponent buildings in their base (a non-existant issue in Meltdown)
column27: meaning that you get even more map control. Three: You get a massive height advantage which anybody who's played hero shooters before will tell you is crippling. Four: Destroying a Sentry Unit spawns stronger minions
column28: making your push even harder
column29: despite having to go farther. Despite the fact you are at your own base you have almost every disadvantage possible if you lose your Sentry
column30: including you can't even take your own personal objectives (Such as mercenary camps) simply because they destroyed your first unit. Overall it feels like while it had promise there are too many issues that it makes one push a game decider even though you don't have to push far.\n-Capture Zones just doesn't seem to fit well into the game for me. Given that most characters are offense or hold oriented (even if they are supporting
column31: they support the above two)
column32: it feels weird having to DEFEND and objective instead of counter pushing
column33: in a game like this.\n\nNow for campaign. To me it's simply a mess. The first chapter is interesting
column34: but after that it starts getting repetitive. Out of the 8 chapters
column35: 2 are escort missions (Because those are fun

column37: and you get a scoring system (which is needed to unlock characters
column38: unless you wanna grind levels out to get a full roster...) that doesn't seem reliable. I could do it flawlessly and get a worse score than screwing up multiple ways for "reasons".\nIn terms of a story
column39: it's simply boring to me. The basic story is "Rendain has drug many stars into a void
column40: and is going for the last one that everybody is at"
column42: but after that you have "We have built a machine

column44: let me say). The dialogue is pretty golden in the campaign
column45: but while I get a good laugh
column46: I find that I just... am not interested in the story which is bad for a story driven mode.\n\nIn terms of music... I can't remember even the title theme. It's suiting
column47: not memorable music through the game.\n\nThe Gear System needs a special mention. You get gear by playing
column48: and you can use the in-round currency to buy it to buff yourself for the rest of the round. The only problem is... you get no guarantees on what gear you can get. This means for optimal loadouts you are relying not on skill
column49: or knowledge but rather luck. You should never have to rely on luck in a competitive game to be able to do as well as you can.\n\nIn terms of graphics
column50: don't let the minimum requirements fool you. So many maps can and WILL cause visual lag on even pretty high end computers. It is poorly optimized
column51: and it doesn't help when there is a large amount of visual noise making it hard to see what you are attempting to shoot at. Even a simple grenade can cause a massive fire-ball followed by a plume of smoke
column52: and that can lose enemies more often than should.\nThat all said

which is pretty clever.

reviewText:
I reeeeally wanted to like this game. Absolutely adore Gearbox as developers.

I preordered this game like 3+ months before it was released; I was so excited.

I played the app on release, simultaneously with the game. I love skins, so I wanted the bonus one.

But this game...It just doesn't have any heart in it...I just don't feel it.

The look or a Borderlands is there, the humor is there...But the heart isn't.

The servers have already emptied out a few weeks after release, you can't play any but 1 gamemode, and even then you're looking at crazy high queue times.

I don't know what they can do to bring this game back to life; but it just doesn't have that feel like their other games do.

I guess; compare it to Borderlands: The Pre-Sequal. Doesn't have the same charm their other games do.

I dunno. $70USD ($100~AUD) is a stupidly high price tag for a game that feels much like a demo.

I would hold onto your money for now. Sorry Gearbox...I'll be there for you when you release something along the lines of BL1/2 quality...But this is not it.

reviewText:
I was excited for the release of this game to be released, but it just doesn't live up to expectations.

The coop is OK for the first couple of playthroughs, but it quickly becomes tired.  There are way better coop games out there that cost a lot less money.  Any of the Borderlands games (also made by gearbox) will provide a better coop experience than this game.  There are a total of eight story missions, and each one takes 20-30 minutes to play through.  So that's about 8 hours worth of gameplay before it get's boring.

In a full priced game I would expect to be able to play all of the characters from the beginning, but that's not the case here.  You have to reach a certain level for your account, or achieve certain milestones, to unlock most of the characters.  I would expect that kind of grind from a free to play title.

On top of that the characters are not very satisfying to play.  Their skills feel...meh, but hey at least the cool down timers are short so you can spam them relentlessly.

The PVP portion of the game....well just....no.  There are plenty of reviews and discussion threads that point out the many flaws (and there are MANY) in that game mode so I'll spare you.  There are too many other MOBAs out there that are well done and satisfying to play.

In short, don't waste your time or money on this game.

reviewText:
For the price (I pre-Ordered the Digital Deluxe edition) I find BattleBorn completely worth it (Although my FPS was trash, I found a few fixes which I will address later) The humor, gameplay and replayability with the gear and XP leveling is completely up my alley. I love the colours and the astonishing beauty of this game (Even on low, lol) I would definitely reccomend this game.

FOR THOSE OF YOU WITH BAD/TERRIBLE FPS
I would reccomend changing your PoplarEngine.ini file (Documents\My Games\Battleborn\PoplarGame\Config) with these edits:

MaxParticleResize=100
bSmoothFrameRate=FALSE
DynamicLights=True
DynamicShadows=False
LightEnvironmentShadows=False
MotionBlur=False
DepthOfField=False
AmbientOcclusion=False
bAllowLightShafts=False
Distortion=False
FilteredDistortion=False
DropParticleDistortion=False
LensFlares=False
FogVolumes=False
AllowRadialBlur=False
ParticleLODBias=0
DetailMode=0
MaxAnisotropy=16
FXAA=False
Lowering your view distance also helps.

And those of you with AMD cards, change your PhysX to medium (I got much better FPS when I did with my AMD card) as this will make it pull from your graphics card and not your processor as is what happens when you set it to low. Also setting anisotropic filtering to 16x and not 0 got me better performance. Not saying this will work for you, but it did for me. Happy Playing! (btw Screw Galilea rn)

The queue times are 45 min plus, then when you do get a game you are paired against level 100 players and lose in 5 mins. Most of the characters are locked so those players at 100 are using characters that aren't even available to you.

That being said the main campain was fun, all the characters that i played have great personality and well voice acted.

reviewText:
5/10

This will sound too harsh, but I would probably return this game if I could. The mechanics are interesting and they have combined a lot of awesome aspects from the genre to give it a good structure, collectable items, free skins, etc. Given time I'm sure it will become more polished and expand but as it stands, wait. I am terrible at this game to be fair, but match making is flat out terrible. level 20+ teams should not be fighting against people who are sub level 10. I want to like this game, I am trying. The storymode, which consists of 8-9 different 30min missions, is fun enough when you are in a full group.. But then again, you can drop with no penalty and start up a different game.

Overall gameplay is pretty much chaos though. If you're great at knocking off crits and kiting, you'll be heavily rewarded. If not, you're terrible and deserve to go 0-10 because you screwed up early in the match and died trying to finish off the ranged with 10 hp and you're a stoopid melee and now you're level 3 while the other team has 2 level 7s who run a train on your whole team. Don't know how the XP works, but it's not my friend.

(Also, the dialogue is funny-ish. If you were expecting borderlands-esque humor, it's there... everyone is Jack and each line attempts to be a one liner.)

reviewText:
Someone who enjoyed the open beta, I regret buying the game, even more so buying it from a website that doesn't offer refunds just to get a discount.

Pros:
- The combat
- The amount of characters
- The art style (personal preference)

Cons:
- The matchmaking (low ranks vs high ranks)
- More dull characters then intersting ones
- Bland campaign with boring enemies and bosses and repetitive objectives.
- Getting gear/loot boxes is a choir and doesn't feel rewarding.
- No offline campaign / have fun raging when steam decides to disconnect, booting you from campaign and losing all your progress
- Multiplayer is lackluster and uninteresting, except maybe one game mode.
- Multiplayer maps are unoriginal and bland
- Winning pvp isn't rewarding enough

The game feels rushed and incomplete, more like a side project from gearbox, definitely not worth a full price tag. Felt like more people where playing during open beta then now as a released game. Don't think its very successful and enjoyable as another game people like to compare it too. Plus I have alot more faith in that company to actually keep things balance and current than gearbox, which still hasn't fixed the horrendous matchmaking. My only thought would be it doesnt really matter, because there isnt even enough people playing to get a fair game with people in the range rank, you would be waiting for days.

reviewText:
Disclaimer: Played the Closed Technical Test and the Open Beta. Pre-ordered during Open Beta.

Claimer: Take some Borderlands, sprinkle more colour on top of everything, simmer on a slow flame slowly stirring in things from the MOBA cookbook. Let cool over a breeze of badassitude.

Evil Aliens Are Eating Suns! More news at eight.

The leader of an arguably evil empire has struck a deal with otherworldly monster aliens to serve them rather than die at their hands and now the rest of his empire along with four other factions are forced to work together on a last stand at the last surviving star in the universe before it too goes out against their former ruler. Who wasn't even a real ruler, he just usurped the throne from a beloved Empress, the dastard.

Like Borderlands, Battleborn takes every thinkable (and several unthinkable) reference and trope in sci-fi and fantasy and throws them into the blender to create its world - so you have more lunky awkward robots to laugh at and pound away, walking shout-outs and awesome walk-away-from-explosion scenes to enjoy. The visual side is seriously informed by saturday morning cartoons as evidenced by the badassful animated introduction that replaced the pre-rendered 3D animations of the Beta.

Unlike Borderlands, Battleborn is built to focus on multiplayer. You can still do stuff solo - but it won't be real" solo

co-op or competitive play.

Why? Simple. The games match making system is soooo horribly broken right now, you dont get to experience the good" and "fun" part of the game very often.

well... take a look at this screenshot to see how broken match making is.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=685572212

And before you reply with "Level doesnt mean anything"... WRONG. Here is how level means something.

1. High rank typically means more experience playing the game modes. Knowing what you are supposed to be doing on a map is 50% of playing the game (the other 50% is skill). A team of all sub level 15s is very unlikely to know what the hell they are doing.

2. Higher level players have most likely ranked up their preferred characters
voteText: unlocking the few extra helix upgrades for them. This isnt very likely for a lower level player.\n\n3. Higher level players have more time/experience put into playing their character

votesHelpful: and this makes a HUGE difference.\n\n4. Higher level also means you have opened more loot packs
votesTotal: which means you have had a much higher chance at getting optimal items for the match. Some level 10 players might not even HAVE some of the item bonuses yet.\n\nAll of these things

reviewText:
Product received for free

This game can be a lot of fun, but some issues are horribly stoping it to be.

- Unbalanced Matches
- Sometimes it takes forever (10 to 20 minutes) to get a match full of people (I read its because it´s region locked, so good luck finding people to play with at 2 am)
- Stuttering, every couple of seconds the game will stutter and framedrops, thats a deal breaker for me, as its a fast peaced game, I need it to be fluent.
- Grindfest, leveling up hero ranks its very slow .. you overall rank speed is somewhat ok.. but leveling individual heroes it´s where it takes a lot of time.

- otherwise, as said, it´s lots of fun. It gets compared to a moba style of game, but in this topic, it feels somewhat incomplete... Incursion mode being only one lane... making it a big push foward and backwards.. brute force, not much strategy involved... if it had 3 lanes would be awesome. There a mode with 2 lanes, but somehow so confusing it doesnt feel like it but as a big lane somewhat together.

- Story mode is cool, great humor, but as a solo player very challenging , already in normal mode, where strugegling a lot you end up with a bronze medal. You can play with other people, but you can´t choose the Chapter you want to play, you get 3 choices and this ones get voted...ifg you are looking for completing that one chapter, you have to wait for the luck of getting that particular chapter opted for vote, and get voted for.

Final words: This game it´s fun, but it could so much more fun if the described flaws would get ironed out...

reviewText:
Battleborn, while offering brief glimpses of entertainment, is generally a flop of a game.

I wish I could get a refund on the $60 I spent on it for myself and the other copy I purchased for a friend.

It's not an intrinsically bad game, but the fatal mistake Battleborn continually makes is that it tries to be good at too many things at once. Rather than focusing on PVP or a solid PVE-Campaign, Battleborn attempts to be good at both, but fails to do so with either.

The PVP is grossly unbalanced, as many of the other reviews have pointed out. Some classes are wildly more powerful than others. As of the latest patch, a tank" class (Isic) is capable of doing more damage than most of the actual damage classes. Other characters can run up to you and kill you before you're even capable of responding in an effective manner.

I've found the PVE campaign to be a boring grindfest of the same types of mobs over and over. There are maybe 5 or 6 actual enemy NPC's you will fight throughout the entire game. Really pathetic.

This game is certainly not worth the $60.00 price tag. It feels like an Early Access game. The patch roll-outs seem really slow
date: and I'm not really sure as to whether or not Gearbox cares about what players are saying or not. Although some attempts to balance classes seem to have been made
recommended: the pace with which these updates are being applied is dismal.\n\nOverall
hoursPlayed: I cannot recommend Battleborn in its current state. If you're looking for a solid class-based multiplayer shooter
voteText: go with Overwatch or Team Fortress 2. If you're looking for a third / first person MOBA
helpfulPercent: go with Smite. Battleborn attempts to blend both genres but fails to do it. Spend your money elsewhere."

reviewText: As someone who isn't a huge fan of MOBAs I absolutely love this game. There are elements that have been added which I think make the game a lot more enjoyable, such as loot and the singleplayer story which is broken into sections that are basically MMO Dungeons done in first person.  Surprisingly the most fun I've had so far is in these group dungeons, they are quite well done. It doesn't hurt that the game is so vibrant and that the characters are all unique and have lots of personality. That's not to say that the multiplayer isn't fun, it's a blast as well. I'm still learning the MOBA part of things and trying not to play like a straight up shooter but so far I've had some nail biting matches that were literally down to the last second.\n\nOverall it's definitely worth the price of admission and it's a shame that so many people will overlook this game becuase of Overwatch, which shares very little in common with this game and is basically TF2 made by Blizzard.

reviewText: I played the beta before buying the game and enjoyed the experience. Over all the game is amazing and a great buy for anyone who enjoys what 2k makes. The charcter and gear system once mastered can be fun and creative, allowing for a wide variety of personalization and specilization. This game is not without its fults however since changing the friendly and enemy colors affects the enemy appearence and helth bar in game, however when it comes to a cut scene or image that goes with the mission audio their colors represent what they would appear like if the team colors were left at defult within the game options, breaking what would be perfect, customizable immersion. Also when playing online campaign for the first time there is a choice of either episode one or two. If there is a vote for the second mission and you beat the boss it will not unlock that miswsion to replay in private campaign since you have to win the vote for and beat the missions in order to unlock them publicly. A simple fix would be to give players the choice to either play the missions in order or random vote. That way people who want to play through the campaign publicly can play while those who want instant action and a random set of maps can go off to another server. I believe that these pronblems are a result of  a rushed open beta, developer inexperience, mislabeling and deadlines that had to be met. Battleborn has the potential and backing to become a great game. Personaly I feel as if the game is an FPS with a few MOBA elements that allow it to be more than a remake or parody of a formern game.

reviewText: Battleborn is a pretty decent game. While not worth the full ticket price (Though with updates I am sure it eventually will warrant it's asking price), I would reccomend picking up the game. I personally enjoy the versatile assortment of characters, each one so far feeling vastly different than another. One thing I would reccomend is getting a friend to buy the game to play it with you. While Battleborn is fun playing solo, much like the borderlands series, the experince is enhanced through cooperative play. Even in the pvp modes, having a friend to ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t to makes things a lot more interesting and leads to a more rewarding experince, in my opinion.\n\nI'd give the game an 8/10 with a possible increase to nine with the release of the dlc characters and episodes.

reviewText: Overall I love Battleborn and have had lots of fun with this game, but it may not be a game for everyone. This game sets itself apart from others with a blend of FPS and MOBA elements to create an unique experience and does a good job implementing features of both genres. The Co-op story mode and PvP modes provide plenty of fun especially when you grab some friends jump into the game. A lot of effort has been put into the characters to give each their own personality and interactions with other characters flushed out the story behind each Battleborn. While I enjoy the game there are some issues with performance, matchmaking, and balancing that needs to be improved for a better experience in the future, but overall a great game.

reviewText:
Battleborn..

Not only is it a multiplayer game(This isnt Overwatch) its also a Story mode game which you can play with up to 4 friends or play private if you would like.

Its a game you can sit down for hours and still have a blast no matter how long you play.

The controls to the game are easy to get the hang of or if you prefer it does offer PC controller support

It also features a ingame marketplace that you use to purchase gear crates for your characters with the in game currency you get from just playing the game or better yet you might get lucky and open a box that contains a skin or taunt for your toon  (Wouldnt that be nice)

The Heros are amazing with all the abilites and ultimate moves they have and the combat is very well blanced.

The more you play the more things you earn and can unlock such as titles, gear crates, skins, etc..

reviewText: This is a good game that's unfortunately getting overshadowed by Overwatch when really the two games don't have much in common. If anything, you'll get your money worth of content in Battleborn more than you would in Overwatch. There's decent PvE and fun PvP, with a hefty progression and unlock system. reviewText:
About 5 hours into this game and I was having so much fun that I thought I would take a break and write a brief review.

After a chain of over hyped game (Arkham Kinight, Evolve, Watch Dogs, Titan Fall) I was so happy to get one that was truly worth waiting for.

Right after the prologue/tutorial I jumped into a live 5 person team of random players; the wait was about 30 seconds and the action was intense immediately and never really let up. The world is colorful, the enemies were plentiful and the objective was clear.

My team won that first match even though I really didn't know how to use my abilities (I played as Orandi); all subsequent games have also been a blast.


As expected the characters each have a unique skill set which means a different play style; and for me that translates into more fun.

The keyboard and mouse controls were smooth and highly responsive (I use Razer's Orbweaver and Logitech's G700 mouse).

Base on my first impressions I'll probably be getting and Season Pass. I'm also a big Blizzard fan and have played all of their games a lot, including the Overwatch open beta.  That is another great one and I'll end up getting Overwatch as well. We're lucky to get 2 very good games in Battleborn and Overwatch; each different from the other but both offering loads of fun.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
This game is just a ton of fun... The characters are all interesting and funny and each is unique in their own way. Gearbox did a great job giving each character his/her own identity. The story mode is fun and can be extremely challenging, though the story is pretty lacking - the levels are more like doing PVE raids.

I don't see myself putting it down any time soon. It's especially fun with a friend or party, which makes the price a little steep. I recommend waiting for a sale when you and a friend or two can pick it up together. There is a bit of a learning curve and teamwork is very necessary, so keep that in mind. It might take a few games to get used to it and really figure out what's going on.

Lastly, and like many have mentioned in these reviews: STOP COMPARING THIS GAME TO OVERWATCH

reviewText: Overall I love Battleborn and have had lots of fun with this game, but it may not be a game for everyone. This game sets itself apart from others with a blend of FPS and MOBA elements to create an unique experience and does a good job implementing features of both genres. The Co-op story mode and PvP modes provide plenty of fun especially when you grab some friends jump into the game. A lot of effort has been put into the characters to give each their own personality and interactions with other characters flushed out the story behind each Battleborn. While I enjoy the game there are some issues with performance, matchmaking, and balancing that needs to be improved for a better experience in the future, but overall a great game.

reviewText:
* I've never written a review before, so bear this in mind.*

Battleborn, I was hesitant to purchase this; that I admit. Infact, I waited until it went on sale, even at that I was a little worried.

Well, my verdict? This is an absolute blast, I regret nothing! I wish I dove into it sooner.

You will LOVE this game, if:

1) You like the gameplay of Borderlands.
2) A MOBA fan.
3) Oh you like Smite? Well... Guess what?! This is less clunky feeling!

As for the nay sayers in previous comments.
This game isn't DEAD, sure it's not BOOMING. But, I've yet to play the same opponents twice.

I blame the negative reviews on perspective:

People are saying OverWatch is better. Y'know what? OverWatch is a strictly FPS shooter, their competition is of another breed. Meanwhile, Battleborn is an FPS MOBA. It's really not hard to get into at all. The playerbase isn't so toxic to hate on you during a match.

Their cries for OverPowered characters? Look how much time they've put in the game.
I find most of these critiques a joke. I dont only mean on Battleborn, but for the rest of Steam.

Sure, balancing isn't perfect ♥♥♥♥♥. It's not nearly as awful as the woeful make it out to be.
Perhaps it wasn't their cup of tea? Maybe they had a rough day? Bugs are really not game-breaking.

Unbalanced matchmaking? That's also a joke. I don't know who thought it was funny, but it's not true. We were a groupd of lowbies (1-18) and we still rocked a game where their accounts were 70-100. It's means nothing. It's not a measure of True Player Skill".

reviewText:
The game is fun, comedy is ok, and the characters are awesome. A lot of heros to try out and master. The campaign can be played solo or with others and takes some time to compleat. The graphics and art style is great it just works.

Online
Online you are put in teams of five in three different  game modes. Incursion will have you destroying each others sentry bots. Capture is controlling certain areas in the map. Then in Meltdown you will escort minions to sacrificial altars giving you points. You can also play the campaign online.

I really enjoyed the game but I recommend playing with friends as a team. Everyone I know is a console gamer so I don't have anyone to play with on PC. I have only won 7 games online but I'm still having fun and I will continue playing.

reviewText:
An incredibly fun and unique game. I've truly enjoyed playing it, and will continue to keep playing. It gets far more criticism than it deserves.

Cons:

- Optimization. Unfortunately, you are going to need newer hardware to play this game. Gearbox has stated that they are working on this.
- On-screen effects. It can be a little disorienting at times. However, it's not nearly as bad once you get used to it. Gearbox has stated that they are working on this.
- Lack of variety in campaign. I do find the story fun in multiplayer, but it could certainly use more variety. Single player is a little boring for sure.
- Player numbers. *THIS IS AN ISSUE IF YOU ARE OUTSIDE OF THE US OR EU* As of right now (May 29th), there are thousands of people playing. I live in the US, and I've never had an issue finding a match or teammates for the campaign. Match queues have been very quick.
- No good tutorial for multiplayer in the game. If you want to be competent in multiplayer, you'll have to do a little research. Luckily, the game does allow you to practice against teams of bots. I highly recommend practice before jumping into online matches.

Neutral:

- It's a complex game. Make no mistake, this is a MOBA (most multiplayer modes at least). If you go into it playing team deathmatch, you are going to have a bad time. That being said, it's deep and rewarding once you know the rules. It also manages to be fast paced and very fun. I personally love this aspect of the game.
- Grindy. If you want lots of gear, expect to play the campaign a lot. You also have to level up to unlock many of the various characters in the game. Some may love it, others hate it.
- It's new. There are some balance issues and bugs. Some characters are strong and a few are weak. This is to be expected, and gearbox releases new patches (hotfixes) weekly. Right now, I feel that the balance is actually pretty decent.

Pros:

- Fun. Battleborn is a game that doesn't take itself that seriously. You won't find a long-winded ultra-tense MOBA here. While the game is deep, it still manages to be hectic and super fun. It's a rare combination.
- Character design. The characters in this game are awesome. I've played most of them, and they all have unique and interesting skill sets. Whatever playstyle you enjoy, you'll find a character that suits you.
- New content and frequent updates. Gearbox devs are active in the community and listen to feedback. At this time, there are at least four new characters coming in future updates. One has already arrived (Alani).
- Unique. Battleborn's charm and gameplay are refreshing. I am not a fan of MOBAs in general. However, I feel that Battleborn hits the right mix of FPS and MOBA elements. I loved Monday Night Combat. This game scratches that itch.
- Graphics. The environments in the game look great.
- Multiplayer. So far, I've had a lot of fun in multiplayer. You get occassional quitters (early surrender) and toxic players, but that is any multiplayer game.

Overall:

I highly recommend it. Check out some Youtube videos or streamers on Twitch. If it looks like fun, buy it! Just make sure you have a good enough machine to run it on.

reviewText:
The game is undeniably fun.

It didn't give me the best first impression, and after playing a bit in two different beta periods I gave up on the game entirely.  But my friend talked me into playing it with them, and I'm glad they did.

A lot of reviews have already talked about the MOBA/PvP modes, but I'm really loving the co-op.  The mechanics are great, and each of the 8 stages plays out like a mini-dungeon run featuring either point defense/horde, escort, or just great boss fights.  The MOBA-style in-mission leveling and variety of characters keeps each run feeling fresh, and the advanced difficulty runs are just challenging enough to keep things interesting.

Add that to the pretty fun PvP modes, and it's a great package for the price.

My only complaint would be that the humor is, in my opinion, a little forced.  But it has its moments.  The character unlocks might not be popular, but I think they're a solid carrot that keeps that just one more run" high going.


Overall a great game and a steal on sale."

reviewText:
Like Smite but better.

I have been looking forward to this game for awhile now. I did not really do any research before I bought or play any betas, I just saw it was released and bought it. I understood it was basically a first person MOBA made by the same company as borderlands.

Essentially what I have found is an extremely addicting and fun game. I have played LoL for a long time and was always looking for a new MOBA. I tried Smite but I found the characters boring and the game not very unique.

This fixes all of that. Every hero is unique and has a role. There has only been one character I have found to be borderline OP"
date: everything else is relatively balanced. The game has several game modes with Incursion being my favorite.\n\nIncursion is tradtional MOBA gameplay. Creeps follow paths. Instead of towers you have sentries which can move and shoot in their arena. There is no "jungle" but you can kill Thrall NPC's which then turn to your side and push for you. You can purchase and build turrets
hoursPlayed:
and speed boosters. You can find these yellow crystals which are the equivalent of your gold. These build things and allow you to activate your 3 preset items you equiped before the game.

As you level you also have what is called the Helix progression. This is what helps make you unique. For example there is a hero that can overcharge and give allies shields. You can focus on her support role and increase her shield giving abilities with the Helix or you can go the damage route and increase her ability to deal damage to enemy and enable her to tear through enemy shields extremely quickly. Just because you play a certain character doesn't mean you have to play them a specific way.

The best part. It requires actual skill. You can have the best strategy ever in games like DoTA and LoL and it does't require much raw skill. This game you will get destroyed if you cannot hit your enemy with your shots. There are no auto attacks
voteText: you have to manually aim every attack.\n\nI really think it is worth the money. If you are looking for a team based game with a lot of character give it a try. I have thousands of hours on TF2 and this is the closest thing I have played that has given me that amount of enjoyment again."

reviewText: Battleborn is enjoyable. It hits many of the right notes for me with its multiplayer Shooter/MOBA hybrid. The co-op missions, while showing potential, feel more like a tease of what's possible rather than a fully realized vision. I think the game is worth it due to what it offers now (fun maps, objective based PvP) AND the promise of what it can be. It has the spirit of Borderlands (graphics style, writing style), combined with gameplay reminiscent of Monday Night Combat with MOBA tropes.\n\nOh, and the comparisons to Overwatch are a little misguided, IMO. They are two very different games; with Overwatch closer to TF2 (no in-match leveling, no items, no minions/trash mobs, no co-op).

reviewText:
The game is fun, comedy is ok, and the characters are awesome. A lot of heros to try out and master. The campaign can be played solo or with others and takes some time to compleat. The graphics and art style is great it just works.

Online
Online you are put in teams of five in three different  game modes. Incursion will have you destroying each others sentry bots. Capture is controlling certain areas in the map. Then in Meltdown you will escort minions to sacrificial altars giving you points. You can also play the campaign online.

I really enjoyed the game but I recommend playing with friends as a team. Everyone I know is a console gamer so I don't have anyone to play with on PC. I have only won 7 games online but I'm still having fun and I will continue playing.

reviewText:
This game is incredibly fun. I've been thinking a lot why this game can engage me for hours and I have solidified some good reasons.

-Battleborn is light hearted and funny. The characters will taunt each other in multiplayer (without you pressing anything). The story is hilarious and has enourmous replay value, and I chalk it up to how frickin funny it its. The game is super competitive and skill based, but the silliness keeps the mood positive always.

-It's fun even if you're losing. Badly. The characters have fat healthbars. Every fight is interesting, and if someone is beating you, you can see how they are doing it, instead of watching a killcam of you getting quickscoped from across the map for the 10th time. The matches are also multidimensional, and can be about escorting creeps, or holding a position, or putting pressure on an objective, instead of just racking up kills. You can always focus on many aspects.

-The characters are so different. Seriously, you would think that there can only be tanks, assassins, healers, and snipers in games like this. These characters often stradle many of these categories and can be played in weird ways. very interesting.

This game is insanely fun. Drawbacks: poorly optimized (low fps is common), few map choices. More are coming out, but I wish they released more maps. Not too big of an issue though. I can see how people would be dissatisfied with $60 for this (not that much content), but the replayability is huge, and it is INSANELY fun. Very unique game.
