reviewText:
Good game, no glitches (not that i've seen or heard of), fun multiplayer adds replay value.

37h playtime when writing this.

Short version: Hero based FPS (25 heros to start) mashup of Borderlands and TFC2. Solo/co-op missions (8 mission campaign) to level and/or farm gear, multiplayer 5vs5 in 3 game styles, 2 maps each. More content to come.

no microtransactions or P2win. In game currency transactions only.

Graphics: 7/10 -similar to borderlands 2, cartoony, nothing special, but runs fast on lower end PCs and consols. Sometimes it's too flashy and colorful, not for epileptic people.

Solo/co-op missions 7/10 +Variety of styles, (kill, capture, escort, etc) with good dialog, humor and level design. -Story is pretty simple and can use more depth, it is pretty short with 8 missions. -Replayable, but they don't really change, so it gets repetative.

Multiplayer 8/10 +Here is where it really shines. 3 Sytles, more to come. 2 maps each, more to come. It's fun, fast paced and requires teamwork. -Needs work on matchmaking and some balance issue, but devs are taking comunity imput and already working on this from Beta and post launch patches.

Charaters design: 9/10 25 +Very unique characters, I have played over half. +You need to learn each one, there are variations of the 10 skill options and then loadouts to add to each for custom gameplay. + They look great and added Taunts and skins are unlockable for in game currency. + 25 to start, at least 5 more to come soon.

Overall very enjoyable, especially with friends, or add people in-game with Steam.
New game, so population is growing, matchmaking is being optimize because sometimes it's slow (1-6 min wait) for 5v5  pvp.

If you are comparing this to overwatch, then you are comparing about 35% of this game to 100% of overwatch, since this game offers much more. There are many difference and I sugguest you watch some youtube to see the different gameplay parts to understand. I have played both, and mostly like both, but I do prefer Battleborn for now.

reviewText:
Don't buy this game if you want to play any sort of balanced pvp. The equipment system is basically a randomized Runes and Masteries system from league of legends which leaves no room for balanced online multiplayer.

There doesn't seem to be any kind of matchmaking for online multiplayer, for example my first online match was a nice spread of levels that looked very close to
My team: 2, 2, 4, 72, 10
Enemy team: 10, 2, 24, 30, 13
The level 72 proceeded to faceroll the enemy team

There's also no sort of leaver protection/failsafe. If you get into character selection with 4 or less people you are /forced/ to play the game through to surrender vote.

You could play for the story but the game is rather easy.

Playing as the sniper class I was able to stand in front of a boss and melee the thing to death without dropping below 80% hp. Sure it was on normal but it seems that you have to complete the levels before being able to attempt higher ranks of it. The missions are stale and slow, we found ourselves wondering; What do we do now?" multiple times before the mission finally pipes up and tells us where to go.

Don't waste your time unless you're just in it for the borderlands humor."

reviewText:
Despite the games many infuriating flaws I still find myself coming back to play. Over and over.

Yes, matchmaking is finicky. Yes, players can currently cheese one of the incursion maps (which I have never witnessed myself thus far). Yes some heroes are a downright pita to be matched up against (early days yet to be able to give an opinion on balance updates - unlike some players I can understand we can't have a patch every other day). And yes, there urgently needs to be a way to report toxic players.

But it is fun. It's got a great single player and co-operative campaign, which may seem short at 8 missions but I've found the replayability is there and I really don't mind doing this for gear upgrades. The recent addition of Advanced matchmaking has been a godsend and I've been lucky with the PUGS I've played with. Except on The Saboteur. That mission is cancer.

Like Borderlands before it, the games oozes character. The campaign is full of the Borderlands standard of humour we've come to know and love but I think what really stands out is the characterisation of the games heroes. I've found myself doing the Lore challenges not just for the hero specific legendary gear attached but... gasp... the lore. Oscar Mike being a personal favourite.

Multiplayer wise, I've come to prefer Incursion. The games most moba-like game mode. And while I've experienced the same issues as others being matched against higher level premades I have not had any issues waiting for matches. The longest waits being on the 2-3 minute side. Hero balance is an ongoing thing and it's quite early to comment specifically on how well Gearbox is doing with this, other than there has been some balance tweaks in hotfixes already and they have shown an interest in hearing what the players have to say.  I've not as much been infuriated by certain characters being overpowered but moreso with certain premade compositions (read as: I need friends and to not play alone). Obviously being moba-like, communication and co-ordination is key and a helpful pug can turn the tide against higher level premades. Sometimes. Kinda.

Performance wise I've had some hiccups on certain missions and maps. I am however playing on a low to mid range rig and with most settings at medium and AA and Physx off I've had a steady experience with fps and no other performance issues preventing me from playing and enjoying the game.

I do hope the game offers a demo or free weekend at some point as there are (and rightfully so) a lot of mixed views on this game the best way to decide if it is for you is to test the waters for yourself.

Personally, I'm having fun and while I can see why some aren't I'm deciding to keep the faith in GBX. At least for now.

reviewText:
It pains me to give this game a thumbs down, since the basic mechanics of the game are very good. But its flaws just utterly hinder any enjoyment you can get from this game.

Let's start with what the game does well. You have 25 characters which all have their unique twist and don't just feel like a reskin of the same 3-4 characters. You have melee, sniper, support, healer, skirmisher, flying characters, high DPS, defenders, tanks and all kinds of in between characters to this.  Discovering all the different characters is quite a lot of fun, The PvP, when well matched, is one of the most entertaining ones I have seen due to the wide variety of characters. There's also the voice acting. Hey it's Gearbox, you expect great voice acting, you get awesome voice acting. Hearing a german aristocrat say I declare war on all liberal arts major" is just awesome.

Now for what the game does not so well. The PvE

reviewText:
All the PC problems popping up aren't guaranteed to affect you considering most PCs aren't having issue.

Matchmaking taking 30-45 mins to start is a massive exaggeration. It's closer to 3-10 mins max if you're on at least NA servers. I can't say for other servers.

If a comparison is made to overwatch you can stop reading because the review will not be worth your time. Any comparison made to the game is ignorant and more often than not made by someone who hasn't tried battleborn.

The game has MOBA like pvp, 3 modes, 2 maps each, with gear and buildables.

A story mode with 8 levels each allowing gear and credit collection while getting xp for yourself and characters.

Each of the 26 characters can level up to 15 and every level will give you something either for the character or as a loot pack. They also have 5 lore challenges each to work towards unlocking to get more info on the characters. They each have a helix as well that allows 1 of 2-3 skill augments each level that last for the match up to level 10.

I reccomend this game as all the issues are being addressed. Gearbox has put out an update each week since its launch to tweak balances and modes.

This games marketing was very little, and the ignoramuses comparing it to overwatch have also hindered it, but battleborn is worth a try, especially now that it's discounted. Grab a copy, grab some friends, and have fun.

Hopefully this helped some on the fence.

reviewText:
Look. I really really want to like this game. The gunplay can be good, the jokes are funny. But overall? I can't reccomend it.
Why?
Because most of the characters will take days to unlock, which means if you're playstyle is that of one of the upper tier characters you have no reason to ever play this game to the point where it'd even resemble fun.
I'm also inclined to warn you that matchmaking tends to suck, as you'll often have one team clearly much farther ahead of the other in skill (or to phrase it differently, you'll usually see a team of level 10's fighting nothing but people at 50+)
But the visuals are good, the story missions are fun, the comedy tends to be funny (though not for everyone clearly)
Whereas the gunplay can be spotty, getting decent equipment is luck of the draw, and most of the community prefers to pull a surrender after 4 minutes of playing rather than finishing the game.

Maybe it'll be better later on, but for right now I can't give it a solid reccomendation.

reviewText: Battleborn has made its way into my heart as one of my all time favorite games. I do beleive that it does need some fine tuning though. During my ~150 hours of gameplay I have encounted some bugs. Although these bugs are not gamebreaking in the least, it is still dissapointing to see these flaws. There is also a slight issue with matchmaking. Allthough the issue does exist and is annoying, it is not nearly as bad as some people seem to make it out to be. Some players feel that the matching is broken and flawed as we are put into matchs where players have massive level differences. The matchmaking does not look at levels when creating a match it looks at W/L ratio so a high level who has only played pve and lost all their pvp matchs (ex. 1) they will be put with a lower level match with people who also have lower W/L ratios. The real issue is that the system doesn't take into account amount won vs lost, so someone who has won 100 matchs but lost 100 matchs can be put agaisnt someone who has only won 1 and lost 1. Other than that I have found this game to have very high replayability especially if you have a cool group of friends to play with.\n\nLastly, I feel this games gets a bad rep as it came out and looks similar to overwatch and paladins. As someone who played the beta for all 3, I will tell you battleborn is very different then paladins and overwatch (which are both very fun and good games in their own right).

reviewText:
I'm not very good at writing long detailed reviews, so I'll just go straight to the point!

I'm absolutely addicted to this game, even playing solo I'm having an absolute blast. It's definitely not a perfect game (Is there really a perfect game?) but it is definitely worth every penny I paid for it! All of the characters are interesting, the gameplay is captivating and the graphics are very appealing.

I would however encourage people to actually research the game before buying - you should do this with any game or purchase, really.

Besides that, I'd like to address some things I've seen in other reviews and on the internet about this game;

I have had no trouble using the menus, absolutely no mouse lag. There could be some quality of life improvements, but overall menus work well.

All game sessions are hosted on public servers. This means they can't be kept open forever and have a timer.

You do not need to touch the higher difficulties to get the best gear to drop. in fact, it is probably more efficient to farm in the easiest difficulty. (The main point of the harder difficulties is to give a challenge. Drop chances are higher, but RNG is still RNG.)

I am now Commander Rank 86. The only loot packs I've bought are Faction Packs, since I want skins and taunts. All the gear I've gotten is from the small amount of time I've spent playing through the PvE content. Excluding Legendary gear, the drops are extremely generous. I don't even know what to do with all this gear! (So no, you do not need to buy loot packs at all)

Unfortunately PvP doesn't reward you with loot, and you get less credits from it than PvE, so if you want that Sweet Loot you'll probably have to delve into PvE at some point.

Expect a Grind. With a capital G. Make it bold too. A lot of stuff needs unlocking. A rather artificial way to prolong the lifetime of the game, but I've been having such a blast with the game that I don't mind. If you dont like the idea of not getting everything the game has to offer immediately, you should probably pass on the game.
About characters, their unlock requirements and Lore Challenges:   Most characters are locked behind challenges (most of them are a cakewalk, some might be a little more challenging - Ghalts unlock is probably the hardest, at Command Rank 40 or by completing all story missions on Advanced with at least a silver medal) If you enjoy the game, none of the character unlocks should be that hard. You gain Command Ranks by playing and all but the DLC characters can be unlocked by CR. You'll get all characters by naturally playing the game, even the DLC ones. (If you are willing to save the credits for it.) I had no trouble unlocking all the characters, though I understand that might not be the case for everyone.

DLC characters are 47,500 a pop. That is a pretty hefty sum, but as stated above, you'll get all the credits you need by playing the game. And there really isn't a need to spend credits on anything else. It would be nice if you could try out the character before shelling out the credits for it, but alas, there is no Try mode in the game. So do check out some gameplay videos first!
EDIT: You can actually Refund bought characters - at least if they are bought with the Hero Key, not sure about credits yet.

Season Pass owners get access to DLC characters a week earlier than everyone else. They also get a Hero Key, which they can use to immedately unlock DLC characters. They can also use the Hero Key on default characters. The Hero Key will be refunded once the original unlock requirement for that character has been met. Shelling out the extra money can significantly lower the grind needed for the characters. Gearbox is a business afterall, SP needs some appeal.

All characters have 5 Lore challenges. Behind these challenges are, you guessed it, Lore about the character in question and the Battleborn Universe. Upon completing all challenges, you get a character specific legendary gear. They'll boost some stats and will also have a unique legendary effect appicable only to the character the legendary was made for.
For some characters, the Lore Challenges are extremely easy and you can complete most of them in a couple of matches.
Unfortunately not all of these Lore Challenges were created equal. There are many of them, so you'd be best off checking the wiki to see and judge for yourself. Personally I think the Lore Challenges need some major tweaking.
Some can only be completed in PvP, some can only be completed in PvE. Some are much harder to complete in PvP than in PvE.


That's all I can come up with now. This ended up being pretty long and incoherent so I'll stop here. If you have further questions, try heading to the official Battleborn Forums, or it's Reddit page. Gearbox Devs check both!
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I love this game so much. While there are things that make me grumble on occasion, they aren't things that happen often or can be patched out. So, here's the rundown.

Pros:
-Super fun PvE campaigns, with Advanced difficulties. They're also relatively forgiving if you want to try out a new character since most people on your team will know what they are doing.
-Every character feels uniquely different, and has a full fledged skill tree for every match to try new builds, unlockable skills, unlockable lore, and unlockable taunts, and not all of them are show in the command menu.
-Speaking of lore, all the characters are very well developed! Their lore will explain how they became such badasses and their trials before you met them like Rath, or reveal things like Oscar Mike's terrible fear of spiders.
-Very humorous, and all the
characters have dozens of different lines. Even the campaign dialogue will change depending on the characters present.
-Tons of replayability due to the unlocks.
-PvP is challenging but satisfying when you win.
-The soundtrack is pretty damn good.
-Fast paced crazy action, just like Borderlands.

Cons:
-Sometimes enemies will bug out and be stuck behind a wall, where you can't kill them. This can prevent progress, but can usually be solved by AOE abilites, waiting, or in the case of timed levels walking away.
-PvP is HARD when you first start. Expect to die a lot.
-Not everyone thinks to be mindful of their teammates and stick together, or they stand in front of you where you can't shoot around them. This game is very cooperative in every aspect but single player, so you can't leave your healers and snipers out in the open.
-Getting pushed into a wall by an Attikus and Kelvin then pummeled sucks, because you're literally stuck between a rock and a hard place.
-Melee tanks are a little squishy, so you have to be very mindful of staying in motion.
-Poor optimization. I run this on medium settings and still get  big FPS drops on certain levels, (*cough* I'm looking at you Saboteur...) whereas I can run MGSV on high and never get any drops except for maybe like 30 seconds rarely.

I'm hoping I wrote about an equal amount for both, as I can't really tell on my phone. But really, give this game a chance, even if you wait for a free weekend, a sale, or even have a friend that owns it share their steam library with you. It has a solid story, varied game play, and is just made to be fun.

reviewText:
Review in progress.

This review is with less than 24 hours of play.  This review can change with more playtime.

Gearbox has put together a very competent Frankenstein's monster.

If you enjoy the quirky - if not at times cringeworthy - sense of humor and aesthetic of the borderlands games, the PVE dungeons in Destiny and Hero based MOBA games, then this game is probably for you.

Battleborn is a jack of all trades that doesn't do the best at any one thing - compared to each contemporary in that genre - but as a sum-of-all-parts it's a great package that will keep you addicted.

PVP plays as an objective based MOBA with a substantial upgrade path from level 1 - 10 in each match and limited item customization via items you can bring into the game and use currency you build during a match to activate.

It plays a lot like a first person MOBA but is still different enough to entice people, like myself, who are not big MOBA fans.  It's truly a hybrid between the world of first person shooters and MOBA games in a way that rewards skilled FPS players but doesn't overly punish people who prefer isometric 3rd person action/strategy games.

On the flip side, if you're a skilled FPS player who thinks he's going to go it alone - rambo style - then you're in for a rude awakening because teamwork is definitely the key.

This is true in PVP and PVE which plays a lot like a strike in Destiny.  PVE levels are 5 player co-op missions that take roughly 45 minutes to complete.  They're easy enough that you won't feel frustrated by your teammates if they refuse to work as a team but difficult enough that you WILL fail if everyone is off doing their own thing.  The challenge comes in meeting objectives rather than being killed by enemy NPCs and my group failed to defend genermcjiggerwattchamacallits at least 2 - failing the entire mission - because we allowed ourselves to scatter off.

Littered through out the levels are upgrade pods that will allow you to purchase, with money you get from killing enemies/from the environment, different types of turrets, traps, and UAVs that help you.

Speaking of which, you WILL need to make use of these in order to win the levels and determinig which of these to spend your currency on, and at what time, is where the challenge comes into play.

If you scoffed each time Dinklebot said hold off these enemies while I scan this wall" then you'll be disappointed to know that many of the levels have multiple parts where you're doing just that.  Only
date: in Battleborn you're protecting a device from destruction.\n\nWhen you mix the constant waves of enemies with the upgradable traps/turrets
recommended: it feels a lot like a first person tower defense game.\n\nBattleborn truly is a hybrid of all sorts."

reviewText: From announcement to just before Open Beta, I could care less about this game.  I loved Borderlands but just scratched my head at this IP.  However, open beta came around and I decided to give it a try since it's Gearbox and all.  First run was on PS4 since that beta started first.  After I did a solo story mission, my outlook hadn't changed much.  But then something clicked.  The second run and following runs (co-op and all)  it began to grow on me and I became a huge fan.  Once the PC open beta started I was fully ingulfed and knew this game was amazing.\n\nI highly recommend trying it if you're still in doubt.  It's good fun!  Worth a buy for sure!

reviewText:
Great game.

For Overwatch I felt they forgot to add gameplay or story. Quality voice acting is pointless if the game is shallow murder the opposite team.

Doom 4 had horrible graphics with forced AA hiding a console game

Paragon was pretty but turns out wasn't really a shooter. The ranged attacks in that game don't go but a few feet. Very disappointing as these are the guys who made the new UT4 engine. I was the most excited about this one and the most disappointed.

I initially had the lowest hopes for Battleborn based on it being be the dev who brought us Duke Nukem and Colonial Marines. I also am not really a fan of cartoony art styles as they almost always mean console style low skill cap shooter.

I was very pleasantly surprised to find a high skill cap shooter (or melee-er) with multiple fun modes that could be built out. Very highly recommend for PC gamers and veteran shooter players. Terrific voice acting and the world feels like an expansion of Borderlands in terms of storytelling which can be a positive or a negative as it is admittedly a bit childish in it's humor.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
All in all, a solid first person shooter.

The pro's - that good old Borderlands feel.
Good old Borderlands everything really - graphics, sound effects, unique character specialisation and abilities. (I swear that crazy 6 armed dark magic female alien has the exact same voice as the little girl from the last of the Borderlands franchise, and she's bat @#$% crazy!).

The cons - The story (campaign was way too short). This leads to the game feeling extremely repetitive if you don't play against other human players. Even with new characters being unlocked frequently as you progress through the story, even the new abilities and weapons can't cover the fact that you've become a farmer after your first completion of the campaign. Although I haven't tried it yet, my only solution would be to avoid repeating for gold medal completion and simply head on to the next level of difficulty.

I would've loved to have seen more variety in this game, but yes.. I'm well aware that it's NOT the new Borderlands. Well done to the developers, keep it up.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Fun game - a lot of interesting characters to play, each with different playstyles and strengths.  Its flaw is the same flaw as every multiplayer game - your multiplayer experience is dependent on the folks you play with.  Play with some friends in a coordinated team you you'll have a better chance of a good time.  It's got a single-player/co-op story mode too, which allows you to get used to the game & some of the characters, and allows you to unlock more characters and gear mods for your player.  For all you Borderlands fans - this is NOT like Borderlands at all, though it retains much of the humor found in Borderlands games.

reviewText: Incredible game. I love the enemies you fight and the boss fights are intense. Advanced mode and hardcore give another layer of depth to this game. With my average dungeon running me 30 minutes, I can easily have fun for an hour or two and still feel like I've accomplished something and am moving forward. There is a real sense of progression in this game. I can play one hero and only one and spend hundreds of hours unlocking things on that hero. Or I can play one of the other super-unique Heros a few times each and still progress my account. Did I mention I'm only talking about the PvE half of this game? There is another half that is PVP with extremely different maps from King of the hill to death match to MOBA. I'll spend a few hundred more hours on PvE before I get bored and start playing PVP.\n\n100% recommend

reviewText: Battleborn is a fast paces, action-packed game which is not to be taken lightly - despite it's quirky and fun style there is a certain depth to the gameplay that isnt immediately apparent. There are several systems in the game including Loadouts, Helix and Shards which will take time to get used to, but outside of that it's a very fun game for both casual and competitive minded players.\n\nIt doesn't come without isses, with people reporting framerate drops and with disconnections as of yet going unpunished in online play, there is room for improvement on a technical level, but as for the game itself, I cannot think of many glaring issues which would cause me to avoid this game. I enjoy the game, the characters feel unique, and the dialogue and writing is reminiscant of the much loved Borderlands games, which work together to make a great game to play solo or with friends, whether you are more interesting in the PVE or PVP side of the game.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I think this game is fantastic!

I find it combines MMO style PvE instances (with loot/gear, boss mechanics and team roles) with MOBA style tactical PvP in a fps/first person/action game-kinda way.

As someone who has played and loved MOBA games, FPS, and MMORPG's, in both PvE and PvP modes and who has got bored of the big franchise games of the modern era and the very familiar gameplay they offer, I am finding this to be a real breath of fresh air!

This game is my new time sink!

It has it faults in places and areas where things could be added that would be very useful. Things like a pre and post match lobby are missing and if it was included it would provide a much better social aspect whereby players can make friends with team-mates and add them to friends lists to team up with later. I appreciate however that some things I would like will not come as the game is not a solely PC game and is more popular on consoles. Consoles do not easily support said features and as such they may never come. Smaller things that could be added would be a buff and debuff hud icon with effect timers etc and these features could work on both as they are just a HUD change/addition.

The game isn't hugely popular on PC either and players in countries with lower active player counts report long queue times. I would say my average queue time is approx 45 secs in normal and advanced mode PvE instancing and in the Incursion and Meltdown PvP modes. I am from the UK and guess I play on the EU servers.

The game seems simple on face value but is actually quite complex in regards to the Heroes" and their individual play-styles and what they are suited too. Characters excel in certain roles and are terrible in others and not knowing this could make the game seem really easy or incredibly hard depending on which character you chose to play what mission or PvP role. To me this is great as I love tactical planning for victory or the chance to play a badly suited class for a mission as a challenge!

I don't know what else to say really. Maybe watch some streams and see what you think of the game-play in action. I love it but we are all different! I hope this at least offers a slight perspective of someone really enjoying the game."

reviewText: The hero shooter that is BADASS, seriously this game is outrageously fun. The game modes are all very solid, each gives enough variety to the game so that it stays fresh consistently. From a technical standpoint it runs strong on my rig (R9 390, FX-8350) even in Ultra Wide 2560x1080. Which it does support but the cutscenes are all for the most part in 16:9 and not 21:9 but that's to be expected. Overall a great game which I plan on sinking plenty more hours into, which is around 40 spent combined from technical to launch.

reviewText: This game is really fun. There's a lot of content to unlock, a large variety of characters to select from, and has a great personality to it.\n\nMy biggest gripes is the uneven matchmaking that will either pair you up with really skilled players or with people that don't know what they're doing. reviewText:
I do not play moba's nor fps's, nor am I playing overwatch. I am a somewhat casual gamer who plays strictly for fun!
I simply tried this during the open beta and found something very fun indeed, it was hard at first and took some learning but eventually I became comfortable with it and I have experinced much joy hence!
Frankly the combat is at a wonderful pace, characters are just hearty enough to make a mistake or two, early level anyway. Abilities are unique and very effectual if applied with the propper context, like real combat, you must be smart!
And the game forces you to learn, sometimes in matches you cant win or seemingly but I have made comebacks from hell in incursion and this game plays smoothly and tight as destiny which I've spent many hours with.
Many people like to compare this game to other currently on the market and submit that for each thing Battleborn does there is a game which may satisfy you better, that is hogwash good sirs! As no game has for me.
I submit that Battleborn is at it's core a polished fiesta of fun characters and in depth inspired game play that offers hours of time/minion/baby slaying with no regrets!

reviewText:
I played the hell out of this game during the beta, and I play it somewhat regularly now that its released, and it's a wonderfully interesting game.

The combat is fantastic, and uses missile/projectile based hits instead of hitreg like CoD, which is far more satisfying and consistent in FPS terms.
The game has a lot of very interesting, fun and beautiful graphics, and artwork, with quirkly voice acting that gives it a wonderful immersive charm.

It's incredibly well done with some faults.

The biggest problem with the game right now isn't anything wrong with the game itself, but rather that it lacks players.
It's a MOBA and like any MOBA it needs a large player base to function well.

It would be a lot more fun and involving if it had more players to make more balanced matches and just have more overall players to work with any anytime of day.

It's a good game and deserves a lot larger player base than it already has.

reviewText:
Battleborn is pretty great IMO.  It takes two of my favorite genres of games and mashes them together.  At it's core it's a MOBA and on the surface it's an FPS.  The art style is great and if you like Borderlands you are going to like this game.  The humor is also very much like Borderlands and it never takes itself too seriously, which is a good thing.   The characters are well designed and their interactions with one another in game can be pretty hilarious.

I've played through all the story missions albeit I did it solo they were still fun and engaging missions.  I could see how going in with a full group on the advanced difficulty could up the ante and make it a little more satisfying to beat.   I've spent the bulk of my 90 hours playing the competitive multiplayer though and that for me is where the meat of this game is.  It is a lot of fun playing with friends but it can be just as fun if you use the in game voice chat to communicate with your teammates.

I hope more people will try out this game, it's very unique and there really isn't any other game out there like it right now.  Hope this was helpful and see you guys on the battlefield.

reviewText:
Battleborn is great. It really is. It combines a lot of elements, FPS, MOBA, and even MMO-like raids into one great package. With 25 heroes to choose from, and 5 (free) DLC heroes upcoming, it's a great deal.

However, there are a number of issues that need addressing - the low population means that matchmaking is absolutely awful, if you can even get a game. This may change if more people buy it, which I hope they do. From experience, it doesn't have the level of toxicity that some other MOBAs have, and that's a good thing.

If you have the patience to learn the ins and outs of an FPS-MOBA hybrid, you'll enjoy yourself. Just don't buy it if you're in Australia, you're gonna have a bad time.

reviewText:
My net feelings about this game are 100% positive, but I can't really ignore some of the negatives coming out of the other reviews. I can tell you right off the bat to disregard anyone whose primary argument is go play Overwatch. None of the reviews I've read like that had anything useful to say, just biased hate and buyer's remorse.

At the time of writing this I have 32 hours in the game and have only been playing the PvE story content. This does mean I've repeated the missions many times over but I've honestly found them all to be quite replayable/enjoyable.  Including the prologue and the finale there's 8 of these missions that easily take 40-50 minutes each. You can unlock most things in the game through these missions with the only major exceptions being lore and achivements related to fighting other players in a PvP environment. Additionally, achievements that require match victories can actually be done by beating missions too.

I've found pretty much all the characters to be quite memorable without even having played them all; whether or not they're enjoyable is another matter. There's a couple whose personalities I just can't stand (Bouldur, Benedict) but beyond that their ability sets and histories are actually unique. Unlocking lore and skins/taunts for characters you enjoy is very satisfying and it simply adds to the game universe, and if you enjoy hoarding lore en masse then you'll easily get your money's worth out of this game several times over.

Now, for the negatives, such as optimization issues in the game. I can tell you right now if you have an AMD graphics card you'll want to disable PhysX as soon as possible and then just try to find settings that help your performance. While I don't know how bad performance is in the smaller multiplayer maps I do know that at least a couple of the PvE missions are suffering from some serious optimization issues in a couple sections of the mission, and sometimes regardless of the missions you're in you may just have some rampant effects crushing your fps as the game in general doesn't seem to play  nicely with AMD GPUs. Don't get too discouraged though, bout 95% of my experience has been perfectly smooth gameplay, but the 5% is pretty noticeable when your frames are crippled.

I've heard a lot of people complaining about PvP matchmaking being imbalanced and some frustrations with certain Battleborn being overpowered. I think the offenders were nerfed recently, but I can't speak much on this as I have yet to try versus. That being said, I got this game to escape from the expectations of hardcore competitive play that I usually expect to see in games like League of Legends. It could be that its imbalanced enough to not be fun, but when I get on to play this game I get on to play a specific character because I enjoy their abilities and their personality. I've heard some pretty funny statements and interactions come out the few times I've had my ♥♥♥ handed to me in the PvE missions, so my outlook is I look forward to hearing the full compliment of my character's voice lines when I start playing PvP. I'm just looking to have some casual fun and I think this game is in a prime position to allow just that without riding the esports hype train that other games do.

Lastly it seems Gearbox just gets a lot of hate in general. I'll be honest, I don't know ♥♥♥♥ about this or why this is. I've absolutely loved the Borderlands series and I pre-ordered the deluxe edition of this game with no regrets. I know some major complaints are the $20 off sale in the 2K store that occurred 2 weeks after the game released, but I imagine that was mostly to try to compete with Overwatch's release. A number of players feel ripped off because they payed for it at full price, and while I can appreciate the sentiment, I also feel those players had no business buying the game in the first place. When I spend money on a game, when I pre-ordered Battleborn, I did so with the intention of not giving two ♥♥♥♥♥ if it went on sale the next day. I wanted to spend that money on the game to support its developers in addition to getting access to the most content because I think its worth it. Objectively anyone could argue whether or not its worth the value, I've penny pinched on plenty of games by waiting for sales, but when I find a game that really looks fun and I have the money I will pay full price and more for it. And I still think Battleborn is worth that full price, there's a fair bit of DLC that seems to be planned for release down the road that can be secured with the deluxe edition or buy the season pass separately.

Beyond these points I can't argue much else. Most of the other negative reviews out there are valid (except if they're calling it dead already, that's just unfair) and if they turn you off from the game then don't spend the money on it. I think, like borderlands, this is a game that's only going to get better with time as more content becomes available. I look forward to seeing where the story goes and what future of the games PvP content is, and even if it suffers at present I definitely seeing it experiencing several population spikes as future content is released and sales for the game become available through Steam.

Also if you do nothing else there's a pretty badass animation that occurs right before the prologue mission in the game. Look it up on youtube Battleborn Prologue Animation." It got me and friends super hype to play the game and on its own the animation is pretty great."

reviewText:
Product received for free

Battleborn is a brilliant game played by too many of the wrong people.

The timing is unfortunate in its release along side Overwatch and I think a lot of people just ended up in the wrong game. I own both of them and have played them both pretty extensively. I enjoy them both but for completely different reasons. Getting the most out of either required that you know what you are getting into so as not to feel shorted once either delivers exactly what they said they would.

Battleborn is strategic where as Overwatch is tactical.

A lot of planning has to be done prior to the match starting. Characters and load out choices cannot be changed once the match starts. The TTK in BB is much longer than OW giving players more time to use abilities, counter enemies, and work the battlefield. The inclusion of various structures around the arena adds another level of strategy as players must choose whether to stay and help on the front lines, or fall back to enlist NPCs, construct support stations, spawn special units, or simply use their collected shards to activate their gear.

Overwatch is a highly visceral, extremely fast paced pit fight where TTK is quite often instantaneous. Each character has a maximum of around three abilities that do not change making the game more similar to an arcade style shooter. Characters can be swapped out mid-match as players jockey for the best team counter composition but the way you play them is always the same.

Battleborn is chess where OW is checkers.

BB is a very involved experience that can overwhelm players with choices while OW is a get in and get out quick fix intended to sate the appetite of a particular demographic of players. This is not wrong and I myself continue to log into OW when that is the itch I am looking to scratch. However, BB on the other hand is where I go when I am looking for a more filling, cerebral experience.

We are in a time in the gaming industry when fast, easy gratification is the selling point and Blizzard is no fool. They crafted Overwatch and then distilled it down to the purest form of this ideal and wrapped it in a highly polished layer of sex knowing that it would sell like crazy to a market where anything involving more than two steps or 5 minutes is considered too hard, or in need of a quality of life" nerf. This is why they have simple sexy characters

reviewText:
In short: It's great and well worth the money.

It has it all: a PvE singleplayer / coop story campaign with fun-to-fight enemies, 3 different PvP multiplayer modes, tons of very unique and varied heroes to play. The humor is typical Borderlands style and hilarious. You'll discover jokes and references everywhere, even in the menu. It is well done and truly a labor of love, Gearbox made sure you'll discover new jokes and character responses on multiple mission play-throughs. The story may not be very deep, but the setting is cool and interesting and ties it all together.

The skills have punch and feel great, the movement is perfect. The music is lovely, the voice acting on a high level, even the german voices did a movie-quality performance!

The game blends multiple RPG / MOBA elements into the first person shooter at its core, which adds a lot of depth and things to discover. This adds a lot of replay value, as you can not only mix up your team composition, but also skill your selected hero differently each match, to adapt to the game.

The core mechanics are highly addicting, be it destroying those orange shards and collecting their pieces, searching the map for chests or simply the fluid combat and movement.

Yes, the graphical style might put some of you off, but it is like the Saturday morning cartoons we all loved to watch in our childhood. You'll get used to it, and in combination with the humor and the fun atmosphere, you'll enjoy your stay.

A word about the endless comparison to Overwatch: As thousands of people told you before me: These two games are very different. Overwatch is like Team Fortress 2 with heroes, a super simple and fast-paced shooter with hero classes.
Battleborn has much more depth to its gameplay and complexity, it is more tactical and varied. It also offers you solo or coop PvE gameplay, which Overwatch doesn't.

So: Go get Battleborn - You were born for this.

reviewText:
Battleborn is a FPS MOBA type game. The best way I can describe this game is a mix of Borderlands and Smite. After playing the open beta and had an awesome time playing it, I decided to buy the game when it released. I don't regret buying it. It's a lot of fun.

The game has a lot of content. It has a story mode that you can play solo or coop with friends or other players. It also has multiplayer. There are 3 modes in multiplayer: Capture, Incursion and Meltdown. All modes are fun to play, in my opinion.

But what I like the most about Battleborn are the characters. Each character is unique and plays differently. You can build the characters in different ways (depending on your playstyle), there are a lot of challenges to complete with each character and a lot more to do. The game runs well and I like the graphics. The only thing I don't like is the queue times, but besides that I think Battleborn is an awesome game.

I definitely recommend this game. My score for Battleborn: 9.5/10

reviewText:
Played it in the open beta, loved it. Only played story and never touched PVP during that time. Tried as many characters as I could.

Release day comes out and it's still a blast. There are many pros and many cons to the game, but if you're just looking for an overall, I say it's a positive that could only get better with added content. So we'll start with the good.

+The main idea of the game is that there are tons of characters to choose from, each with a different playstyle, and that playstyle can morph and mold to the situation with each level they gain. No build is concrete, but some talents are overwhelmingly more powerful than others. I think that will change very soon.
+Story mode is difficult, but casual. You can take your time, play any character you want, and still have a decent run in solo and cooperative alike. The challenge really seems to reward groups that think about the composition(I.E.: Tank, Damage, Healer).
+Story mode is replayable through audiologs and different character interactions, along with just playing a different character in the same setting. Mobs aren't randomized, but loot is, so you can plan ahead and expect what's coming. This isn't a rogue-like adventure, sadly.
+Loot exists. It's not awesome, but it exists. And the legendary gear isn't amazing, but it does feel good to use.
+All the characters are wacky and awesome in their own special way, the Gearbox way. Which, are all customizable to an extent through unlocks gained by replaying them and doing challenges to unlock their lore entries.
+Versus mode is very competitive. A mixture of first-person and moba-like playability is what Battleborn shot for, and it landed it correctly. Now it just needs to fix a few problems...

And that's where the cons come in.

-The talent system, also called Helix Mutation, is currently pretty badly balanced in my opinion. When it comes to PVE and PVP alike, there are a lot of talents which are just overwhelmingly and objectively better. Plus, you have to unlock some of them, which means going into PVP without a fully leveled character might put you at a disadvantage. Example: Galilea. I'm certain they'll address this kind of problem eventually.
-Story mode can be frustrating on some maps. Defense mainly, when you have to protect a core from being destroyed, and you have no way of repairing it or directly defending it besides killing the monsters attacking it before they manage to demolish it. This aspect might not be fixed, but it can be played around once you learn the game a bit more.
-You can just look up the audio logs and spoil the replayability from wacky banter that way.
-Loot isn't awesome, but it exists. The stats are random, but follow an idea of quality, tpye, and rarity, which all dictate how much shards it costs to activate. Sometimes it matters how much it costs. In PVP, a legendary item can be great, but not if the enemy is running three white items which boost their combat power by a lot right away. But this is going into specifics. If you don't get serious about gear, this won't matter too much.
-There isn't a heck of a lot of customization you can do for the characters. YET.
--PVP altogether. Very competitive. NEVER QUEUE ALONE, EVER. If you do, pick an independant DPS character and prey on the weak. You'll usually get ganged up on and die a lot, which will lead to a loss, if your team composition isn't perfect, if your team isn't in sync with what you're doing, or if the enemy is using an exploit to win. Eventually, this has to be changed, because balancing is important to the growth of any competitive game. As of this review, I can say that the PVP is fun as long as you do it as a team. Battleborn is a team game from start to finish, not like a traditional moba where the team splits into lanes and judges the early game on individual preformance". If you don't communicate for team versus team warfare right away
date: there won't be much of a team left for the disadvantaged. At least there's a surrender feature...\n---FRAMES. One big problem with Battleborn right now is frame problems with a lot of machines. I know at least 4 people personally who run this under 30FPS with lowest graphics possible

hoursPlayed: and even then I lose a lot of frames when I get into the thick of combat. If this game was more third person
voteText: it would be a bit easier I believe
helpfulPercent: but that just isn't what the game was built around. I believe it's because the game was a bit rushed and didn't get properly optimized...So I am VERY MUCH HOPING it will be addressed
votesHelpful: fixed
votesTotal: and resolved for good
votesFunny: so that machines that date earlier than 2015 can run this game without a hitch.\n\nBut even with most of these(PVP centric
commentsCount: honestly) many cons

reviewText:
I'd recommend this game for around $40 I paid a little less than that, and feel its a better price point for what you get.  There isn't a ton of content, but all the characters are where the game really shines and its fun unlocking and mastering them.  It'd be great to have more maps and levels but all in all its a fun game.

I enjoy the familiar humor, art direction and voice actors from the borderlands series.

Half the game is Borderlandish co-op play and the other half is a 5vs5 MOBA game.

If you're a diehard fan of Borderlands and want more of it then get this, if you want this strictly for the MOBA aspects you might want to check out Overwatch which this game gets compared to a lot. (even though I don't think its fare since that's really only what half this game is about)

reviewText: TL DR: solid 7.5/10, only really brough down by repetitive Story mode\n\nSo as you can see i haven't played a huge amount, but i played in the Beta quite a lot, and Overall if i were to say something about this game i would say, buy it for Multiplayer, the Multiplayer was quite fun and in general the game is fun, but the Story mode, the story mode disappointed me SO MUCH, not because of a bad plot or unlikeable characters, but because after the first couple of missions, it was INCREDIBLY repetitive. Almost every mission became either Escort or Defend this point, all ending with a boss battle, i got to the second last mission before i decided it was not worth it. I honestly regret pre-ordering it because i got bored with it so fast. But the game itself isn't bad, in fact it is rather fun and if you have a group of friends to play it with it could be pretty fun, just don't pay 70 bucks for it (almost 100 in AUD)

reviewText:
I figured I needed to do my part for this game and write a decent review for once, I rarely if ever write reviews but some bad reviews are bad for nonsense reasons. So here goes.

Battleborn is a first person MOBA-esque game. It has a small campaign of 8 missions and a prologue which can be beaten with 1-5 players in under 8 hours. The meat of the game (to me) is in the multiplayer. There are 3 game modes with 6 maps.

Capture - 3 points on the map where you have to hold to get points, more plots you own the more points you get.
Incursion - Most similar to a moba gameplay style. You escort minions across the map in order to attack their 2 sentries. That is the main goal, whoever kills both sentries or whoever has the best score after 30 mins, wins.
Meltdown - 2 lanes where minions spawn on both sides. The goal is to get your minions into the enemies grinder, for every minion scored you get an amount of points (depending on how big the minion was) while also killing enemy minions and players in order to stop them from scoring.

Lets go through some pros and cons

Cons
1. Balance - Many people complain about balance issues with specific characters but Gearbox has been issueing out patches every week and modifying characters often. For the most part the blanace is great, out of 26 current characters there are very few that need work (underpowered or overpowered).
2. Matchmaking - I will not lie, the community of the game is small-ish with the peak at around 2k players and the lowest around 800+. I have heard if you live in another country especially Aus then you might have some connectivity problems as there is even less people playing there. The largest population comes from the US. I live in the US and get connected in 1-5 minutes, the downside is in the early morning aroudn 4-9am the game is pretty quiet and can sometimes cause me to wait up to 20-30 minutes for a match.
3. Performance - The game is not optimized very well and I have heard it is worse for AMD users. I have a Gtx760 with an AMD Fx-8350, running on an HDD and i have to turn my settings to low-med to get a steady framerate above 50.

Those are the 3 main issues with the game that many people have, but lets get to the Pros.

Pros
1. Characters - There are currently 26 characters to choose from that all feel unique and all are really fun to handle. There are 3 types of Classes, Support (Healers/Shielders), DPS (Ranged/Melee) and Tanks (Ranged/Melee). I personally play support most often and enjoy all 6 of them.
2. Loot - After each match you get credits that you can save up and buy lootpacks to modify your loadout (3 peices of gear per loadout, loadout chosen before the game starts). The gear is diverse and has a lot of great stats to play around with. Alternatively you can do campaign missions, they feel like a dungeon in an MMO to me where you run them over and over and you find loot there with the possibility of getting mission specific legendary items which have great stats and a special trait attached to them.
3. Gameplay - I love the gameplay, on any gamemode I have a great time. I prefer Incursion since it takes the longest and you have a higher chance at maxing out your character and doing some real damage then.
4. Built in voice chat - Its awesome that the game has a built in voice chat system, makes communicating with your teammates that much easier.

Overall Battleborn has its issues for sure, just like any game does. But the gameplay, characters and community make up for that tenfold. I have put in well over 170+ in game hours and I find myself coming back to it every single day to grind some more campaign or to smash face in PVP. I say give it a try.

reviewText:
I generally do not enjoy competitive FPS games, but I really enjoy this game and I feel like I got my money's worth out of it.

I find the PvP enjoyable because you don't have to be amazing to win, you just have to understand how the game works. For example, I have terrible accuracy, but I can spend many rounds getting turrets and accelerators going while taking down the enemy turrets and accelerators. If I am feeling quick, I can also focus on the center field shards – making it take longer for the enemy to activate their items. One match I did this so well that even though the other team was technically more skilled at killing our team we were able to win due to my team fighting back and me spamming large minions onto the battlefield.

But if I get tired of the PvP (usually when I get a string of losses), I can always switch over to the campaign maps and either play with a team or by myself. Either way I get levels, credits, and gear that might help with the PvP game.

Speaking of gear, most gear isn't going to make or break your game. Yeah, legendary gear is really nice but it is expensive to activate and if enough shards aren't available in game then you just wasted an item slot. Often times I will go into a match with 3 common items  and have them all activated within the first 10 minutes of the match or campaign map. It won't win the match for the team but that's a slight edge I am getting that a person equipped with 3 legendaries won't be seeing for a while, if at all.

Finally, I like how in PvP that teams have to be made up of unique characters. You won't have 5 Benedicts flying around blasting the enemy team. While some people see this as a problem, I feel it limits the impact of a character being imbalanced (and let's face it, imbalances are going to happen when you have hero classes, or any game that has classes – it's just the nature of the beast. And the more you have the more likely there will be imbalances). When Galilea was a bit overpowered at release, it wasn't a huge deal for me because I knew I'd never compete against a team of 5 Galileas. Furthermore, by requiring unique characters I never feel like I lost a match because everyone wanted to be the “cool” character.

All in all, I really enjoy this game. I do wish a bit more marketing went into it though because there seems to be a lot of misinformation out as to what this game is actually about.  But if it ends up dying quickly, I still feel I got my money's worth.
voteText: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I was fortunate enough to buy this game on sale, and at the price point I paid for it, I am very pleased.  I do understand those that were upset after paying full price, and see it go on sale. This happens not just in games, but in all free market products, but it still is aggravating.  This is my first Borderland's franchise purchase.

The postives:
1. The Art style is stunning and a real joy to play in.
1. The story liines are fun, For me they alone justify the price. There are diferent mods offering some replaybility.
3. The voice acting is fantastic.
4. The game runs very well. I'm running an i5-4689k paried with 32g and R9 Fury card and I'm at the 60fps constantly

Cons:
1. The AI is dumb. So much so that, fighing with the bots is not the least bit challenging.
2. Could use a slight blalnce pass. Some characters shine, right now and some ohters not so much.
3. The PVP is fun, despite the beforemention balance issue, it's fun and challenging. I have never played a MOBA style game to compare it with, but is very interesting.

Overall, I would say it's worth the price on sale.
